item.title: Acceleration
item.description:
Acceleration means an increase in velocity. Many things that rapidly approach a multifaceted collapse are constantly accelerating, seemingly unmoved by attempts to halt them. There are many reasons for the acceleration and, to name one, economic growth doesn't just result in acceleration, it demands it for its continuance.
We are flooring it.
The soles of our Converse
worn down to bare feet,
the heat of the pedal searing the skin.
We are underage,
under the influence,
Wunderbaum's scent
replaced with burnt rubber.
We no longer know where we're headed
but we think we've caught up
with the horizon,
high above the clouds.
The infant in the backseat is still asleep.
As long as we're going faster,
we tell ourselves
with tears or sweat or it doesn't matter
running down our face,
we'll get there.
Outgoing connections:

Carelessness - Brick on the accelerator, surely you know there is no time to break if someone jumps onto the road?
Catastrophic risks - The probability of a catastrophic event occurring increases with speed and so does its catastrophic magnitude.
Climate change - Despite allegedly attempting to halt it we are currently still accelerating climate change.
Debt - Acceleration drives debt and debt allows maintained acceleration.
Directionlessness - Not only does the propelling forward-force make it difficult to steer, we've lost our sense of direction and the GPS just broke.
End of history - In hindsight it might look like all we wanted was for the collapse to be over and done with as quickly as possible.
Energy consumption increasing - Unfortunately for us, we are not in a vacuum. This means that the faster we move, the more energy is required to accelerate.
Energy - We must accelerate our energy extraction so that we can keep accelerating our energy consumption in order to... Wait, what was it again? Was it progress? Or pay debt? I've forgotten. Something about retirement?
Exponential technology - Exponential developments definitionally require some sort of accelerative property. This one is two-fold. Actors are accelerating development to be the first to arrive at certain exponential technologies and, secondly, those technologies then contribute with additional multipliers to that very same acceleration.
Growth - The growth imperative requires acceleration. Acceleration is what drives growth.
Ignorance of ongoing collapse - We're stuck in the backseat gazing at the raindrop race of acid rain on the window.
Inertia - Each second spent with our foot on the accelerator increases the time it would take to stop were we to ease off the pedal.
Lack of the longterm - Our constant acceleration makes the future ever more uncertain.
Lack of time - Aren't we already too late?
Naive progress narrative - We're moving so fast! Surely you can't mean that this is a sign of anything other than progress?
Profit - Acceleration generates profit and to stay profitable one must keep accelerating.
Sense-making crisis - Nigh on impossible to make sense of the landscape when one passes through it at Mach 3.
Tipping points - We appear to be rushing towards tipping points on multiple fronts.
Too much speed and noise - Sorry, what was that? I can't hear you over the sound of my 2006 Hyundai Getz.

item.title: Access to food
item.description:
Access to food means having access to the necessary energy and nutrients to live. This means living in a place where one can grow fruits and vegetables, one can hunt or fish, raise livestock, forage and gather wild plants and fungi, or have food transported to one's location.
When I give food to the poor, they call me a saint. When I ask why the poor have no food, they call me a communist. Dom Helder Camara
Outgoing connections:

Access to water - Pretty clear connection. To grow food you need water. Also, there are people living close to thirsty avocado farms who don't always have access to neither water nor avocados.
Addiction - The constant ease by which we can reach out for sugar and fat, historically connected to nutrient-dense, hard-to-find food, leads to addictive behavior with regards to our eating habits.
Agriculture - Food being or not being accessible for certain people or places is one of the main drivers of modern agriculture and all it entails.
Ancient sunlight, old sunlight, current sunlight - The energy in the food we grow and eat consists of old sunlight in varying amounts, usually captured, produced, manufactured, and harvested with the energy of ancient sunlight.
Animal views - Many connections here. Here's one. The ease of access to packaged flesh has made many of us mostly unaware or at the very least unthinking, unfeeling about who the flesh comes from.
Biodiversity loss - Most of the previously biodiverse places on Earth are now plantations.
Centralisation - The majority of the people of modernity depend on a select few producers to ensure their access to food.
Cognitive dissonance - How many contemplate where/what/who their food comes from?
Colonialist narratives - Are any of those who grow the coffee I drink whiter or wealthier than me?
Consumerism - If it's there, right in front of you, grab it, eat it. Oreo trees were rare on the savannah, y'know.
Cost of living - One's access to food has clear connections to one's cost of living. Perhaps Russia should leave Ukraine alone simply to lower the price of wheat in Europe?
Dealing with death - Access to endless shelves of food whose deaths we are wholly unaware of. Fattened up and wrapped in plastic we'll live forever.
Deforestation - Forests are unproductive. Whatever that means.
Delusional domination of nature - We've really brought nature to its knees. How else would my stubby cheeto-yellowed fingers have time to write all of this?
Despair - Places which, either suddenly or gradually, lose their access to food rapidly turn to despair when actions fail to remedy the decline.
Ecological crisis - Access to food and our means of getting it is a main driver of our ecological crisis.
Energy - Food directly gives us energy to live.
Energy consumption increasing - The energy that goes into producing food varies a lot depending on what food is being produced.
Genetic modification - GMO continues to be a method of increasing our access to food.
Global supply chains - We want access to certain specific types of food which can't grow where we live so we import things from all over the world.
Healthcare - How would healthcare change if our access to food changes? A lot, I'd guess.
Hedonism - Food is one of life's greatest pleasures. It's also easy to overindulge when the accessible amounts of it seem infinite.
Hemispherical asymmetry (Earth) - "What you people call collapse means living in the same conditions as the people who grow your coffee."
Ignored externalities - What externalities arise from our access to food and how we get it? Oh, so many. The same goes for actions that create areas which lack access to food.
Ignoring diversity - Soy and corn, as far as the eye can see.
Illusion of competence - Since we have a lot of food, that must mean we're really good at producing it. Right?
Illusion of no option - We need to eat. We have no option but to maximise this year's yields no matter what. This is the only way.
Immoral justifications - How do we justify what we eat? How do we justify the inequality of access to food? How do we justify the inefficiency of energy consumption?
Industrial slaughter - We seem to crave constant access to a lot of flesh.
Inequality - The access to food is ridiculously inequal across our planet. Many cocoa farmers have never tasted chocolate.
Insect loss - The methods by which we increase our access to food decreases insect populations and, consequently, eventually, their decline will reduce our access to food.
Lack of a living world view - Growing your own food, even if it's just a pot of basil under a growing lamp in the kitchen, makes the world feel alive, at least a little.
Lack of balance - As with so much, the distribution of access and inaccess to certain foods is out of balance.
Lack of resilient systems - Producing ever more food always feels urgent enough to ignore thoughts of longterm access and food system resilience.
Lack of the longterm - What is the longterm idea, then? A world completely covered in corn plantations and cow shit?
Limits to growth - The actions required to increase and/or maintain our access to food is pushing against plenty of limits. Some have been pushed straight through, for now.
Malnutrition - Malnutrition originates in what food people do or do not have access to.
Mass climate migration - Previously abundant places, now arid, none left. Dry solitary olive trees once proud.
Meat eating - If meat is cheap enough and easy to get, people will eat a lot of it.
Mistreatment of animals - To increase people's access to food we mistreat animals, both in the farms and outside.
Modern slavery - Much that is or resembles slave labour is employed to make food more accessible.
Monocultures (agriculture) - Bigger, better, more, of the same.
Monopolies - The cartel on your dinner plate. Nespresso, what else?
Net negative caloric extraction - We pour barrels of oil into a converter called agriculture and pray for a long term miracle.
Nothing is local - If you could only eat food produced within a radius of a few kilometers of where you live, what would you eat? Ignoring the fact you might not be able to afford it, that is...
Obesity - Humans have historically stayed healthy on a see food diet. Not so much in the present day.
Out of touch with seasons - If we can have food imported from anywhere we lose touch with the seasonal nature of all that lives and grows.
Over-reliance on technology - Modern industrial agriculture is more industry than agriculture.
Poisoning the water, the earth, the air - To ensure or access to food we've decided to try to kill anything that might interfere.
Population growth - More food, more people. To a point.
Resource conflicts - Conflicts over arable land.
Sedentary lifestyles - We don't have to physically work for our food. We don't have to expend calories in order to consume calories.
Story of separation - You are what you eat? What, a vegetable? A dick?
Synthetic biology - Food would be even more accessible if we didn't depend on unpredictable natural annoyances.
The minimisation of all things wild - Ordered rows of crops from pole to pole.
Tragedy of the vanishing commons - Outside of my apartment window, far in the distance, are massive fields of wheat. I've been queueing for a spot of land nearby for five years now. I know those who've queued for 20. All for the freedom of sitting in a chair admiring your homegrown kale.
Transportation infrastructure - Much infrastructure is set up to serve the global food supply chain.
Waste - The way we have access to food matters greatly. It is estimated that up to 40% of food is lost or wasted along the value chain.

item.title: Access to water
item.description:
Things are tougher than we are, just
As earth will always respond
However we mess it about;
Chuck filth in the sea, if you must:
The tides will be clean beyond.
– But what do I feel now? Doubt? Philip Larkin
Access to water means just that. Water for drinking, washing, hearing, seeing, feeling, swimming, fishing, living in and with. I want you to imagine your favourite body of water. Maybe a gurgling creek, a calm forest lake, a beach with crashing waves, whatever comes to mind. In your mind's eye, what do you see? Look around, look at the water's surface, if you see anything underneath, the movement or stillness of the water, what it reflects, how it refracts, if other animals are interacting with it, if anything is disturbing its flow or stillness. What do you hear? What do you smell? Imagine it in as much detail as you can or, even better, actually go there. Now listen to this: "Water is an inorganic compound which is transparent, tasteless, and odorless". The poetry of modernity sure is striking. No wonder we're so happy.
Access to water is access to life, bursting with colour, the taste of the freshness of being, the scent of endless rebirth.
Before enlightenment, chop wood, carry water.
After enlightenment, chop wood, carry water. Zen Buddhist proverb
Outgoing connections:

Access to food - You need access to water to produce food.
Despair - After lack of oxygen, lack of water is top of the list of needs which, if unfulfilled, will turn people towards despair and savagery.
Global supply chains - Clean water is often imported, exported, and transported.
Ignorance of interconnectedness - What do you feel when you stare long enough at the ocean? How would the elite make different decisions if, every day, their children played in creeks polluted through their actions? Direct access to open flowing water has fed into most historical metaphors of interconnectedness. If we've lost that access we will lose that sense.
Lack of resilient systems - Our modern systems for delivering clean water and treating unclean water is a technological marvel, no doubt about it, but it's highly sensitive to disruptions.
Lack of systems thinking - We're currently not acting as if we've thought through what we are doing to the global water system.
Malnutrition - Water is the most vital nutrient.
Mass climate migration - Places previously overflowing with both water and people, now deserts and deserted.
Migration - People move great distances to access water.
Naive progress narrative - Access to clean drinking water and sewage systems is definitely one of humanity's great achievements. Sadly, the cost seem to have been making every natural source of water poisonous in varying degrees. If every step forward has to be talked about in a narrowed sense, I'm not sure I buy it.
Nothing is local - Where does your drinking water come from? Do you know? Where does your sewage go? I believe my drinking water comes from lake Bolmen, almost 200km away from where I live.
Over-reliance on technology - Modern technology is quite magical. It is, however, a tad bit worrying that if we were to lose electricity for more than a few days, clean water would suddenly be difficult, if not impossible, to access.
Planetary boundaries - Direct connection between our access to water and staying within planetary boundaries.
Resource conflicts - How many conflicts about national borders are motivated by accessing water? For simply sources of drinking water it might sound far-fetched but considering land-locked countries fighting for a piece of coast?
Spiritual metacrisis - If you live without being able to access open waters, bubbling brooks, meandering rivers, or quiet creeks... Well, where will the spirit be nourished?
Tragedy of the vanishing commons - I know I'm prone to romanticise but there is something about small groups of people getting their water from the village's central well, or washing by the riverside.
Unheeded warnings - There have been several occurrences, even in the affluent North, where we've gotten dangerously close to not being able to access clean water. Arrows are pointing in a direction where we must listen to these warnings and create solutions that are much more resilient to disruptive conditions.
Violence - Places suddenly lacking clean water will rapidly have its people turn to violence.
War - Wars have been fought over access to water.
Waste - So much water goes to waste.

item.title: Addiction
item.description:
Passion creates, addiction consumes. Gabor Maté
Addictions are disorders characterised by a persistent and intense urge to use a substance and/or engage in a behaviour that produces natural reward, despite whatever negative consequences it may have.
Everyone who reads this will most likely be addicted to something, and I'm not saying that particularly lightly. Craving without self-control is the bread and butter of capitalism. Alcohol and the "typical" drugs, but also food, sugar, shopping, gambling, porn, sex, social media, games, medications, entertainment, TV, work, thought, spiritual, pain, money, exercise, etc. Addiction is the ideal driver of stable, predictable, and sustained consumption and behaviour and, furthermore, an addicted population will exhibit an intrinsic control system towards a life that is in balance with their addiction, rarely deviating too far in any direction. It must surely be rare that heroin addicts protest against the manufacturing of heroin?

item.title: Agriculture
item.description:
Agriculture is the cultivation and caring for the fields of the Earth, generally with the purpose of providing us with food but also fuels, fibres, and other raw materials. It includes crops, livestock, aquaculture, fisheries, and forestry.
The introduction of agricultural practices during the Neolithic revolution more than 10,000 years ago started transitioning most of humanity from a life of hunting and gathering to a settled life of farming. It is not unreasonable to see this as the starting point of many of our predicaments. Even though that may be stating things too simplistically this change in our ways of life undeniably defines much of what life is for us in modern times. Importantly though, the magnitude of this change exploded during the last millennium. A thousand years ago around 4% of Earth's usable land was used for farming. This number today falls somewhere around 50%. With half of our planet being actively cultivated, our agricultural practices matter greatly.
...where ever food is grown the growing of it will raise the same two questions: How do you preserve the land in use? And how do you preserve the people who use the land? Wendell Berry

item.title: Air travel

a concentration;
a symbol... of man's soul; of his determination...
to get outside his body. Virginia Woolf

item.title: Algorithmic curation
item.description:
Once men turned their thinking over to machines in the hope that this would set them free. But that only permitted other men with machines to enslave them. Frank Herbert
Algorithmic curation is the organising and presentation of online media using algorithms designed to personalise the content shown. Its purpose is mainly to increase the platform's revenue by keeping the user coming back and staying for longer. It takes the power of choice and agency from the user and instead puts it in the platform's hands, portraying this switch as something beneficial for the user. Algorithmic curation can be used for good but will mainly follow the incentives and top priorities of the owners of the platforms, these priorities are seldom the well-being of its users.
Algorithmic curation, in its present form and with its current surroundings, leaves us scrolling, paying, unhappy, horny, angry, and unknowingly obedient. Eat the rich.
Move fast and break things. Unless you are breaking stuff, you are not moving fast enough. Mark Zuckerberg
Settle down, Mark, you're moving fast enough.

item.description:

How we choose to divide our usage of ancient, old, and current sunlight is one way of looking at managing our energy predicament.

item.title: Animal views
item.description:
The greatness of a nation and its moral progress can be judged by the way its animals are treated. Mahatma Gandhi
The Abrahamic religions put us, contrary to most spiritual precedents, in a garden where animals where then placed alongside us to be in our service. These religions didn't necessarily start this but they contain clear mythologies of our historical thinking.
As our civilisation has become increasingly sophisticated (bunny ears on that one, I suppose) our views on other animals have become increasingly barbaric. It is important to note that the animal rights movement isn't something new. Jainism and its concept of ahimsa (refraining from the destruction of life) is around 3000 years old and animistic traditions reach back to, and might even in some ways precede, the rise of humans. Different animal views than ours are not just possible, they're historically more common and less complicated to justify.
From strength sweetness
from darkness light
the bees made honey in the lion’s skull Earth

item.title: Apathy
item.description:
Apathy means the absence of suffering, lack of feelings, or passionlessness. More generally however, apathy means simply not caring or not experiencing any emotions. In this sense, apathy is opposed to sympathy (feeling for) and empathy (feeling with) and tends to go hand in hand with inaction, complicity, and passivity. What happens happens, I don't care.
To manage the predicament landscape we must learn to balance and find harmony between the mind and the heart. Dare to care.

item.title: Architecture
item.description:
The specific patterns, out of which a building or a town is made
may be alive or dead. To the extent they are alive, they let our inner
forces loose, and, set us free; but when they are dead they keep
us locked in inner conflict. Christopher Alexander
Architecture is the art and technique of designing human constructions. It is a field which reaches far into the realms of the practical, pragmatic, and utilitarian, while simultaneously reaching into the depths of aesthetics, beauty, and nature. It is also a field whose reach in one direction is easily measured while the other direction isn't. The forces of modernity will then have its way with architecture and this, among other things, is what has lead modern architecture to become what it currently is. Quoting Encyclopedia Britannica's article on architecture, you cannot separate the two reaches of architecture, "because every society—settled or nomadic—has a spatial relationship to the natural world and to other societies, the structures they produce reveal much about their environment (including climate and weather), history, ceremonies, and artistic sensibility, as well as many aspects of daily life".
The world of utility and the world of beauty are not separate realms. Soetsu Yanagi, The Beauty of Everyday Things

item.title: Art
item.description:
Art is about knowledge, skill, craft, ability, preparation, and a mode of existence. Art is the creative expression of culture and life. Art attempts to capture and communicate the unspeakable. Art is the highest level of skill and any skill or act can become art. How and why has art become a predicament? Mainly, but not entirely, due to commodification. In order to live as an artist one needs knowledge of market forces, skills in marketing, efficiency over craft, ability to constrain creativity, prepare to work in advertisement, and reject the mode of existence that art demands. If art dies, culture dies. Luckily, art historically seems to be the one immortal cultural resistance. Art, however, needs to remain free to expand.

item.title: Attention hijacking
item.description:
Attention hijacking means getting someone's attention through force or trickery. It is one of the most seemingly harmless but detrimental crimes against human minds that is accepted as normal in our modern world.
Attention is not merely a passive act. It is a creative one. What we choose to pay attention to is what will spring up out of new sources. What we choose to ignore will wither and die. The dominating culture of our time is a culture obsessed with doing. If we're not doing something we're not doing anything. I'm open to the fact that doing nothing might be the most active thing we can do to change things. Rejecting the economies of attention to instead attend, tend to, and show tenderness to the things that are needed, to that which needs our attention more than ever, that is what truly needs doing. Never before has there been such urgency to not be urgent. Pay attention.

item.title: Avoiding uncertainty
item.description:
Do not view mountains from the scale of human thought. Dogen Zenji
Sometimes we lack simple solutions, adequate answers, and obvious paths forward. This can be tremendously uncomfortable but it is crucial to stay with the questions and uncertainty in order to find the right path. We are bad at this. Mostly, we avoid uncertainty at all cost, instead convincing ourselves and others of the certainty of wrong answers and non-solutions. There are no easy answers to the predicaments we face, nor should there be, since we haven't yet managed to find the right questions.
The only thing that makes life possible is permanent, intolerable uncertainty; not knowing what comes next. Ursula K. Le Guin

item.title: Being reasonable
item.description:
There are so many different kinds of stupidity, and cleverness is one of the worst. Thomas Mann
To be reasonable is, or rather should be, to think through and to understand. Most features of our predicament landscape have arisen due to our commitment to (try to) be reasonable. Unreasonably reasonable. To stop deforestation is not seen as reasonable, to cut down most of the old growth forests apparently is. Reasoning has its merits but it seems we must dare to be a bit unreasonable to be able to manage our modern predicaments. All reasoning tends to follow a certain optimisation and prioritisation and if we haven't figured out what to optimise for (meta-optimisation) our reasoning has little value.
I've been cordially invited to join the visceral realists. I accepted, of course. There was no initiation ceremony. It was better that way. Roberto Bolaño, The Savage Detectives

item.title: Biased evidence selection
item.description:
Biased evidence selection means selecting true facts that support only one side of an argument. A fact being true doesn't mean you have the whole truth about something. Many things in the world have gotten better the past hundred years and many things have gotten worse, only looking at one side will give you an untrue model of the world. Two opposing facts about something can both be true. In fact, truths rarely come without contradictions. Healthcare can both have gotten better and worse. Education can both have gotten better and worse. The Rosling-Pinker narrative tends to go hand in hand with the naive progress narrative claiming that everything is getting better and with time and technology we will end up living in a utopia.
To illustrate this we can look at Hans Rosling's famous example of washing machines. In short, he saw washing machines as a proxy for increased equality and socio-economic status. Women wouldn't need to spend all that time on tough manual labour every day to keep their families' clothes clean. Instead they could now... Well, what? Important to note is that I have no intention of glorifying either poverty or manual labour, rather, I want to point out the opposite side of a commonly one-sided evidence of progress. What the women freed from the labour of washing clothes now have more time for is, most often, working in the global economic system. This could be getting a job in a factory. What might end up happening is that women who had a routine of washing clothes with other women in the community, talking, gossiping, building relations, and being home and caring for their children now have less time in their local community, less time with their children, but more time working for someone else. If a factory gets built near a community, allowing the community to earn enough money to buy washing machines, the factory is seen as a humanitarian success, the backside being a lack of time and potentially a polluted river where once women were working and singing together. Or not. Do we believe we understand?
Out beyond ideas of wrongdoing
and rightdoing, there is a field.
I'll meet you there. When the soul lies down in that grass
the world is too full to talk about. Rumi

item.title: Biodiversity loss
item.description:
From that time forth he believed that the wise man is one who never sets himself apart from other living things, whether they have speech or not, and in later years he strove long to learn what can be learned, in silence, from the eyes of animals, the flight of birds, the great slow gestures of trees. Ursula K. Le Guin, A Wizard of Earthsea
Biodiversity is often defined as "the totality of genes, species, and ecosystems of a region". Another definition might be variety of life. Biodiversity loss could therefore be seen as a reduction in the variety of life.
Biodiversity loss can include the decrease, disappearance, or extinction of a species in a specific area or globally. The current primary driver of biodiversity loss appears to be habitat destruction (mainly for agriculture), which includes deforestation, as well as climate change more generally. The current rate of global biodiversity loss is estimated to be 100 to 1000 higher than the naturally occurring rate which is faster than at any other time in human history.
The ongoing biodiversity loss is sometimes called the holocene extinction, or the sixth extinction.
Outgoing connections:

Acceleration - It seems reasonable to assume that the less biodiversity the planet has the quicker certain disruptive changes can/will be.
Breakdown of information infrastructure - There have existed people with the ability to listen to and understand the ancient languages of other animals and through their words come to understand certain places. A loss of biodiversity also means a loss of the richness of natural information and communication.
Complexity mismatch - The lower the biodiversity of the planet's ecosystems the lower their ability for complex responses to complex disruptions.
Dealing with death - It is of the utmost importance to remember that the technical expression biodiversity loss means death and extinction, too much death for modernity to even attempt to internalise.
Desertification - As an example, certain attempts at reforestation fail completely and instead lead to desertification, most likely because of the lack of biodiversity in planted forests.
Ecological crisis - Reduce biodiversity enough and ecosystems collapse.
Ignorance of ongoing collapse - The collapse of biodiversity is ongoing, not something ahead of us.
Lack of a living world view - How do we return to a view of the world as alive when there are no more birds to sing along with?
Lack of balance - With fewer species left there will most likely occur expansions of certain populations that destabilise the balance of several ecosystems.
Lack of resilient systems - The more diversity and complexity is reduced the less resilient the planet's systems for maintaining homeorhesis become.
Lack of time - The current loss of species is 1,000 to 10,000 times higher than the natural extinction rate. Every day is too late.
Insect loss - Most of the biodiversity loss lies outside the charismatic larger animals we teach children the sounds of, rather there are many insects going extinct. A typical example of attempting to increase pollinators is to introduce honey bees to certain places. This seems good, well-intentioned at least, but unfortunately causes problems for all other bees, bees that don't produce sweetness we can consume.
Malnutrition - How do we even begin to quantify (must we?) the impact biodiversity loss has on the nutrients of the soil, the bacteria in our guts, and the unknown qualities of air, water, sounds, spirits?
Mass climate migration - If a certain species that has supported much of an ecosystem ceases to exist in a certain place there is sometimes nothing left to do but leave.
Meaning crisis - The less life left on the planet, the less we have to live and fight for.
Planetary boundaries - There is undoubtedly a recursive causality with biodiversity loss further pushing planetary boundaries while simultaneously being affected by the pushing past of planetary boundaries.
Poverty - A loss of the richness of the variety of life, what poverty could be more threatening?
Sameness - We'll have fewer species than ever but more of the ones we have. I do love cows but I'm not sure we need every animal to be a cow.
Soil erosion - Do we truly believe we know what keeps the soil alive, what holds it together?
Spiritual metacrisis - Diversity is what breathes spirits into the Earth.
Story of separation - All other animals are dying but we seem to be doing quite well. Did you watch Eurovision yesterday?
The desacration of all places - Nothing makes clearer the silence of the temple than the distant sound of crickets above the bamboo.
The minimisation of all things wild - How can anything be wild without diversity? What is wildness but unending diversity and depth?
Tipping points - At a certain level of biodiversity we might reach a tipping point where global ecosystems completely collapse.
Wisdom crisis - The wisdom of every animal will die with them.

item.title: Blaming the people
item.description:
The system of the free market claims to simply give people what they need and want. If what the people claim to need and want is good for them or not is beyond the market to decide. This rationale leads to the common viewpoint of blaming the people or the individual for whatever effects their actions have on themselves, others, and the planet. According to this viewpoint it is up to each individual to act morally and correctly for their own and others' well-being and, when they fail to do so, take the sole responsibility for their failures. Blaming the people for their behaviour in systems that condition and control them tends to go hand in hand with behaviour that is much more morally corrupt than the behaviour being blamed. Humans are one of the most adaptable animals on Earth and will adapt to whatever systems and conditions they're in. Don't blame people, blame their systems.

item.title: Bullshit jobs
item.description:
Anthropologist David Graeber contends that over half of societal work is pointless and becomes psychologically destructive when paired with work ethic that associates work with self-worth. These meaningless and pointless jobs are what he call bullshit jobs. Graeber categorises these bullshit jobs into five categories; flunkies, who serve to make their superiors feel important; goons, who act to deceive others on behalf of their employer; duct tapers, who temporarily fix problems that could be permanently fixed; box tickers, who create the appearance that something useful is being done when it is not; and taskmasters, who create extra work for those who do not need it. Thinking about most modern knowledge work and it isn't difficult to make the case that they're mostly pointless. Now, not all work has to be useful, rather, this becomes a problem when the bullshit jobs stop us from doing the actual work that needs doing. If you're stoked about the financial incentive for a new mother to prioritise her work as an agile scrum master for an IT-consultancy over her child, seeing it as a sign of our time's superior gender equality, I'm unsure of what to say.
Some criticism of Graeber's work writes that "bullshit 'taskmasters' and 'goons' such as hedge-fund managers or lobbyists reported that they were vastly satisfied with their work, while essential workers like refuse collectors and cleaners often felt their jobs were useless". It is hilarious to me that this isn't written with irony. I'm happy to hear that lobbyists and hedge-fund managers find meaning in their work, it shows me that the plasticity of the human mind is so enormous there might be hope for change. Jesus Christ. Fuck off.
There exist many types of jobs where, if they all stopped, society would become chaos. There are also many jobs where, if they all stopped, not only would nothing happen, we might actually manage to avoid chaos. Although, rest assured that hedge-fund managers are still needed, what would we possibly do without them?

item.title: Bureaucracy
item.description:
To use the machine for control is to be controlled by the machine. James Carse
Bureaucracy is a system of organisation where decisions are made by non-elected officials and is modern civilisation's main administrative system governing any institution. Characterised by hierarchy, continuity, impersonality, and specialised expertise it is the perfect opposite of what our predicament landscape needs. Hierarchy will ensure that the impersonal top level bureaucrats continue gaining from their expertise no matter the external effects. Bureaucracy is a highly centralised form of management and therefore hinders opportunities for emergence and decentralised responses to societal disruptions. Centralisation is not necessarily bad but it reduces a society's ability to respond in a sufficiently complex manner to complex situations.
It is not improbable that while modern civilisation collapses under its own weight, the rulers will trudge through the warm rusted desert sand of our attics, clutching their hairless chests, carrying their desks on their backs, shuffling their feet to the ticking of the typewriters.

item.title: Business-as-usual narrative
item.description:
We've made it this far along this path so why should there be any reason to leave it and stray into the wild? It has given us so much, can't you see, we just need to manage inflation a bit more, calm things down in the Middle East, and move our data to the cloud and then the economy kicks back in and all will be sunshine and continued glory, be a bit realistic! If it isn't that clearly stated there is at least an undercurrent in many people's behaviour that there is no other option than to continue. Business as usual. Except nothing about our modern day business is usual. Most of the things we do are moments of profound strangeness compared to all of human history. Withholding judgements of our acts as good or bad, simply that they are highly unusual.
Our business-as-usual narrative takes for granted that things will continue indefinitely the same way they've been for a tiny part of human history, extrapolating from almost nothing. Many curves of human impact are verticalising, meaning their exponentiality is becoming obvious, and there is nothing business-as-usual about exponential events. Business-as-usual is dead and gone and the sooner we act like it the better.
It is no measure of health to be well adjusted to a profoundly sick society. Jiddu Krishnamurti

item.title: Capitalism
item.description:
We live in capitalism. Its power seems inescapable. So did the divine right of kings. Any human power can be resisted and changed by human beings. Resistance and change often begin in art, and very often in our art, the art of words. Ursula K. Le Guin
Capitalism is an economic system in which the means of production and distribution are privately or corporately owned and development occurs through the accumulation and reinvestment of profits gained in a free market. Capitalism, when it is combined with technological developments and increased energy availability, is probably the main concrete driver behind many of our problems, their current solutions and, importantly, one of the reasons for much of our increased material standard of living. As with most predicaments in the landscape it is crucial to identify not only what to reject, but how to balance the good with the bad for long-term thriving. There is plenty to criticise with the system of capitalism but this has to be done factoring in what it has done well in an attempt to bring that with us into whatever systems we choose as the alternative. For capitalism to continue in its current form there must be (more or less) infinite growth and with us approaching several planetary boundaries, and having passed many of them, continued growth is not a viable option, meaning capitalism most likely isn't one either, at least not in its current form.
...all the operations of capitalism were as meaningless to him as the rites of a primitive religion, as barbaric, as elaborate, and as unnecessary. In a human sacrifice to deity there might be at least a mistaken and terrible beauty; in the rites of the moneychangers, where greed, laziness, and envy were assumed to move all men's acts, even the terrible became banal. Ursula K. Le Guin

item.title: Car-centric design
item.description:
Many cities are designed for cars. As with many predicaments, car-centric design has a complex and recursive causality chain. The more common it is to have a car, the further the distances between shops, workplaces, etc, and the further the distances are the more common it'll be to have a car. Car-centric design has ruined and is ruining our villages, cities, countries, and much of the world and, frankly, makes the world a better place for cars than for humans.
Christopher Alexander et al. write in A Pattern Language, "The problems stem essentially from the fact that a car is so much bigger than a person. Large parking lots, suited for the cars, have all the wrong properties for people. They are too wide; they contain too much pavement; they have no place to linger. In fact, we have noticed that people speed up when they are walking through large parking lots to get out of them as fast as possible". What does their research suggest is a large parking lot, you ask? One that fits more than seven cars. Seven.
Beyond a certain speed, motorized vehicles create remoteness which they alone can shrink. They create distances for all and shrink them for only a few. Ivan Illich

item.title: Carbon fundamentalism

The dominating proxy for climate change has become carbon or, rather, CO2e. Becoming "carbon neutral" seems to be the main goal for many corporations and nations. Putting doubts about the truth of that claim aside, we could probably become carbon neutral or even carbon negative and still continue our vociferous dive into a lifeless, dystopian, scorched earth abyss. We will definitely have to dramatically reduce our carbon dioxide emissions, preferably 50 years ago, but the second best time to plant a tree yadda yadda, however, it will not suffice as a solution to global warming, climate change, or any other predicament. But of course, if you are against domestic abuse and you are currently beating your partner to death, it's a good plan to stop, but it's just the start of the healing process. But it is one thing to read about dragons and another to meet them. Ursula K. Le Guin, A Wizard of Earthsea
A global catastrophic risk or an existential risk is a hypothetical event that could destroy most or all of humanity and/or life on Earth. The majority of existing catastrophic risks are anthropogenic, the exceptions being things like asteroid impacts, volcano eruptions, gamma-ray bursts, and the like. Weighing minimal risk with infinitely bad outcome can lead to nonsensical conclusions.

item.title: Centralisation
item.description:
Centralisation is the process by which the activities of an entity become concentrated within a particular group within that entity, especially activities related to power and control. This power structure creates a hierarchy where those situated in the higher group has influence over the rest of the entity. Centralisation can occur on different scales and in different types of entities and can have many benefits. However, when decisions that threaten the power of the higher group are required for the entity's continued existence things tend to get complicated. Centralised power in an entity also tends to reduce its capacity for complex responses to complex situations, the main reason for this being a lack of possibility for spontaneous emergent behaviour within the entity. We don't need a conductor if we've reached the end of our classical symphony, we need to listen and become jazz musicians in one large multi-faceted improvisational mess. The next big thing is many small things.
When small men begin to cast big shadows, it means that the sun is about to set. Lin Yutang

item.title: Climate change
item.description:
Global changes in average temperature, from equator to poles, means a change in the Earth's climate. The climate is never static but what makes climate change a predicament is the speed at which it is currently happening, threatening the stability of the Earth's climate system and thereby our survival. Put simply, human activities such as burning fossil fuels, deforestation, agricultural practices, and industrial practices add greenhouse gases which trap heat in the lower atmosphere. This leads to global warming and rapid climate change. The global nature of climate change means it contributes to and potentially creates several related predicaments. This is the main reason why climate change specifically is a main focus in the discussion of our continued survival. It is, however, not certain that lowering the global temperature by any means necessary will lead to the desired effects.
In some ways the predicament of climate change has been defined too narrowly, potentially leading to an illusion of understanding its complexity and thereby trusting that a solution is within our grasp as soon as we choose to grab it. This is one reason for why such a "simple" problem hasn't been prioritised at the cost of growth. Every predicament is interrelated but the increase in trapped energy on Earth might end up affecting all of them.
Men argue. Nature acts. Voltaire

Last winter felt pretty cold to me... The massive planetary scale of some predicaments require from us an ability to see through our apathetic tendencies.

item.description:

No? Did you know that the personal carbon footprint was first promoted by British Petroleum? Well, there you go.
Climate footprint, or carbon footprint, is a calculated value or index that enables the comparison of climate-related impacts of different activities. The climate-related impact measured is almost exclusively global warming potential indexed with the unit CO2e, carbon dioxide equivalent.
A bit of inside information. I've worked with many carbon accounting people and they all have one thing in common. They spew more bullshit than they can carbon-offset.

item.title: Clock time
item.description:
It was a Sunday in September. There would only be four. Ali Smith
Modern society rests on the discipline of timekeeping. If you aren't following the time of the clock it will not be possible for you to partake, you will miss everything. Yet, I wonder what we are missing with our minds constantly framed in dates and minutes. When writing this we are currently between Rikka, when birds and frogs start singing the songs of summer, and Shōman, when the plants bloom and the wheat ripens, at least according to the small seasons of Japan. It is morning but the sun is already high in the sky. The swifts should be arriving any day now, after their long flight from Africa, they'll nest in the eaves of our apartment building. They're somehow always on time, as if they knew our wedding day.

It is estimated that humans started using something akin to clocks 5000-6000 years ago with the purpose of organising time more efficiently, most likely related to formal religions and certain social and societal activities. Modern clock time is globally coordinated across time zones whose main origin is the industrial revolution which brought factories and high-speed transportation that required accurate timekeeping. Similarly to the loss of wholeness of space and matter when only considering atoms, something is lost of the wholeness and flow of time when considering seconds. There is undoubtedly a usefulness in timekeeping but one must ask if this usefulness hasn't peaked way before we started to wake up, not with the sun, but with the oscillations of quartz crystals or going to sleep with the resonance of cesium atoms.
Outgoing connections:

Colonialist narratives - One of the main ways for colonialists and missionaries to judge the level of sophistication of primitive peoples was their timekeeping. Introducing the savages to the mechanical clock time of civilisation was a soft nudge towards the cliff.
Lack of a living world view - The ticking of a clock mechanises the world and homogenises all its temporalities.
Lack of time - By wanting to keep time we seem to have none of it.
Misinformation - Does it sound far-fetched to you? The homogeneous nature of clock time is an all-encompassing ambient misinformation campaign. Time is never the same. What would a salmon gain from knowing the average volumetric flow rate of its stream?
Modern slavery - Are you ever not a slave to the clock?
Over-reliance on technology - Don't think you're overly reliant on technology to live your life? I challenge you to live a day, a week, or a month without any access to clock time. If this is not a problem for you, send me an email because I'd like to have a chat about how to end up in your situation.
Quantification - Quantifying time is fundamental for nearly all other quantification.
The minimisation of all things wild - The temporal patterns of nature flow wildly from note to note while we stutter in monotonous staccato.
Weber's iron cage - Clock in, clock out.

item.title: Cognitive dissonance
item.description:
Cognitive dissonance is an experience of disturbance felt when beliefs and actions are contradictory, when the coherence between intentions and effects is lost to such an extent that the harmony between who you think you are, or want to be, clashes with what you actually do. This disturbance or discomfort can be approached in two ways. The first and potentially most prevalent method is to somehow modify, justify, or twist the inner workings to still somehow fit with your behaviour. Rationalisations, selective perception, and selection of confirming evidence are some methods of reducing cognitive dissonance, incoherence, and internal inconsistencies in general. The second method is to meet your cognitive dissonances head-on, firstly coming to terms with the fact that you aren't fully responsible for the tuning of the orchestra, and then working towards harmonious actions with the inherent impossibility of that asymptotic striving, resting in knowing that practice is enlightenment.
If we're all hypocrits, what will you do about it? Always keep in mind the spectral nature of any duality, nothing is purely dissonant or purely harmonious, the gap between them is a wondrous pilgrimage to spend one's life on. Be especially kind to those you meet on the way who seem the most dissonant, they might never have heard the blackbird over the screaming chainsaws.
It's not the note you play that's the wrong note - it's the note you play afterwards that makes it right or wrong. Miles Davis

item.title: Colonialist narratives
item.description:
Today we don't bring god to other countries, we bring the global capitalist economic system. Or do we?
Colonialism is defined as the practice by which powerful countries control less powerful countries in order to increase their own power and wealth. Colonialism is often talked about as something historical, a mistake in the past, imperialist cruelty, but the modern world is packed to the brim with colonialist narratives and actions.
Colonies are the outhouses of the European soul, where a fellow can let his pants down and relax, enjoy the smell of his own shit. [...] Out and down in the colonies, life can be indulged, life and sensuality in all its forms, with no harm done to the Metropolis, nothing to soil those cathedrals, white marble statues, noble thoughts... No word ever gets back. The silences down here are vast enough to absorb all behavior, no matter how dirty, how animal it gets... Thomas Pynchon, Gravity's Rainbow
The real essence of colonialism is the forcing onto other peoples and places of the idea of separate things with impermeable boundaries, the story of separation.

item.title: Complexity mismatch
item.description:
For a system to be resilient it is required to have complex responses to complex threats. When the behaviour of the threat is more complex than the response of the system it is unlikely that the system will respond in a way that ensures its continued existence. This is a complexity mismatch.
A simple illustrating example of a complexity mismatch with regards to ecosystems could be comparing an old growth forest to a planted forest. An old growth forest consisting of an intricate web of thousands or millions of organisms all contributing to the maintenance of their dwelling place makes it resilient to change, its complexity creating a nearly infinite amount of responses to any major destabilising event. In contrast to this a planted forest consisting of a single type of tree will most likely not have the time or the conditions to develop much complexity leading to the risk that even a minor destabilising event causes a complete collapse.

item.title: Craft
item.description:
Craftsmanship names an enduring, basic human impulse, the desire to do a job well for its own sake. Richard Sennett, The Craftsman
Craft is work that requires particular skills and knowledge and, related to craft as a predicament, the proper conditions for such work to be done. There are several factors impacting modern craft, threatening its existence. These factors might become clear when looking more closely at what craft tends to entail. In general, the artisan or craftsman spends time on two types of activities: small scale production and maintenance. Small scale production of goods by one or a few skilled craftsmen stands in opposition to mass-produced goods sold at prices so much lower than what the craftsman can charge to make a living. Maintenance work stands in opposition to disposability and consumerism at large and, further, the majority of mass-produced modern goods are rarely worth maintaining anyway.
The extinction of craft has deeper connotations for us as well, since craft stands tall as one of the most concretely poetic activities, the physical manifestations of human ingenuity. All work should strive to become a craft.
Craftsmanship is not just about creating something beautiful, but about leaving a legacy for generations to come. Richard Sennett, The Craftsman

item.title: Culture wars
item.description:
The wave of the future is not the conquest of the world by a single dogmatic creed but the liberation of the diverse energies of free nations and free men. John F. Kennedy
Modern civilisation is, even more than in the past, a fight to be the one singular entity that wins over all others. Cultures are diverse, they should be. Most cultures have deep roots in unique places, traditions, art, literature, myths, peoples, and stories and cultural complexity, the depth and breadth of cultures, is needed for humanity's continued existence. Culture wars that attempt to erase other cultures either with the purpose of one culture "winning" or for one single homogenised culture to swallow all others will reduce humanity's complexity, meaning we'll be decreasingly capable of tackling any challenges we face.
Without culture, and the relative freedom it implies, society, even when perfect, is but a jungle. This is why any authentic creation is a gift to the future. Albert Camus

item.title: Debt
item.description:
Debt is an obligation that requires one party to pay for borrowed money from another party. The cost for the borrowed money is almost always more than the principal sum, the cost borrowed, since it includes interest. Interest is most often set at a particular rate, a percentage of the amount borrowed. Debt can also be anything that is owed to something or someone else, such as debt owed to coming generations due to our current and past treatment of the planet and its future.
Debt keeps individuals, businesses, governments, and other organisations and financial entities in a constant battle with the assumptions and attitudes about the future. It also makes any serious attempt to manage our predicaments potentially catastrophic since one must keep up with interest rates that depend on growth, assumed or actual, or accept bankruptcy.
Over the past many years we've been sent several reminders that our natural debt needs paying. The interest rate of global rising temperatures due to borrowing more fossil fuels than we can pay for has us staring global existential bankruptcy in the face.
If history shows anything, it is that there's no better way to justify relations founded on violence, to make such relations seem moral, than by reframing them in the language of debt—above all, because it immediately makes it seem that it's the victim who's doing something wrong. David Graeber, Debt

item.title: Deforestation
item.description:
Deforestation is the removal and destruction of forests. The UN FAO estimate that 10 million hectares of forest are cut down each year. Two points of importance: one is that there is a difference between deforestation and net forest loss since forests are also regrowing and being replanted, second is that deforestation peaked in the 1980s. It is, however, also important to note that not all forests are equal and here we run into the potential issue with relying too heavily on quantification. We could most likely make most of the planet net positive in forest growth quite quickly by planting trees faster than we're removing them. The question is if we have a reason to trust our claimed understanding of the differences between artificially planted forests and naturally growing ones. Maybe we do? Do we truly understand what a forest is or are we missing it for all the trees?
There was a time when man* would walk in my woods, but now he has a mind of metal and wheels. He no longer cares for growing things.
---
I am not altogether on anybody’s side, because nobody is altogether on my side, if you understand me: nobody cares for the woods as I care for them, not even Elves nowadays. Treebeard (J.R.R. Tolkien), The Lord of the Rings, * modified quote

item.title: Democracy failing
item.description:
Democracy is a system of government whereby the state is ruled by the people. This is most often achieved by having the rulers elected through voting by the people. Many governments today are, or claim to be, democratically elected governments. There are countless arguments as to why this might not necessarily be the case, and since democracy seems to be the least bad form of government system we have it is vital to not let democracy fail as, I believe, we currently are. The most obvious failings of democracy are technology, especially as it relates to media and information, and economy, specifically wealth disparities and overall expressions of modern capitalism. A simplified view perhaps, but a decent one nonetheless. Technology allows manipulation of the opinions of the masses while capitalism justifies wealth accumulation, and consequently, power disparities. This is not democracy.

item.title: Desertification
item.description:
Desertification is a type of land degradation whereby fertile areas become arid. This typically results from deforestation, drought, or inappropriate agricultural practices.
Comparing a map of global desertification vulnerability with a map of armed conflicts hints at something. What?
Desert, in general, is a very good place to find yourself. Or lose yourself. Maynard James Keenan
Outgoing connections:

Acceleration - The forming of deserts in previously arable land unfortunately accelerates the very factors that cause the desertification in the first place.
Access to food - If I ask you to, in your mind's eye, picture the Middle East, what do you see? Most Syrian refugees in Europe are fleeing from conflict with complicated and complex causes, from an expanding desert that was once called the Fertile Crescent of the Earth.
Access to water - A drier climate drives desertification and desertification drives a drier climate.
Biodiversity loss - As with many things, there's nothing inherently wrong with deserts and even desertification is a natural process supporting certain species that thrive in such conditions. It becomes something problematic when considered in its totality and with its anthropogenic causes. Alright, think of it this way... During an ongoing sixth extinction it isn't great that deserts, which support a much lower biodiversity than forests, are expanding rapidly due to human activities.
Climate change - Many factors here but the most obvious is that deserts barely sequester any CO2 at all compared to forest land. Deserts are hot and contribute in making the world hotter.
Ecological crisis - Deserts are less fertile and complex and barely add anything to the resilience required for ecosystems to continue supporting human life.
Lack of a living world view - If the Earth becomes an arid plain of desert pavement there won't be much heft to the argument of the world being animate and alive.
Mass climate migration - When the sand dunes come leaking in through your front door it becomes increasingly difficult to justify staying when you see what appears to be fertile greenery on the horizon.
Migration - On a smaller but also more general scale than mass climate migration, it is usually economically beneficial to move from a desert to a more prosperous region, especially when deserts are expanding.
Resource conflicts - Firstly, when deserts expand certain natural resources become less available. Secondly, some natural resources such as oil suddenly become more extractable and chaos ensues. Local resource conflicts might escalate over the few patches of remaining greenery while nuclear powers fight over the black gold flowing in the veins of fertile death.
Soil erosion - There is a recursive relationship between soil erosion and desertification where they both cause and expand each other.
Unheeded warnings - Desertification is nothing new and we've known about many of its causes and consequences for thousands of years.
War - I'll let the UN summarise things, "Desertification is a silent, invisible crisis that is destabilizing communities on a global scale. As the effects of climate change undermine livelihoods, inter-ethnic clashes are breaking out within and across states and fragile states are turning to militarization to control the situation. The effects of desertification are increasingly felt globally as victims turn into refugees, internally displaced people and forced migrants or they turn to radicalization, extremism or resource-driven wars for survival. If we are to restore peace, security and international stability in a context where changing weather events are threatening the livelihoods of more and more people, survival options are declining and state capacities are overburdened, then more should be done to combat desertification, reverse land degradation and mitigate the effects of drought. item.title: Directionlessness
item.description:
It seems to me that, in modern society, on the scale of individuals to all of humanity, we have solved the problem of direction by striving to move with higher speed. Going faster and having more will surely yield progress, inexorably lead to everything being better. If you are uncertain, perhaps rightfully so, as to where you should be going it is unwise to tackle this by simply going faster. On the contrary, the less certain you are the slower you should move, instead focusing on getting to grips with your present surroundings. Even if speed, magnitude, accumulation, growth, and restlessness got you to where you are now there are times where you must cease the unceasing motion and consider where you're headed, where your direction should be. If nothing else, stop, find a high point and see what's on the horizon.

item.title: Dispositionism
item.description:
Dispositionism is a term in social psychology used to describe those that believe people's actions are conditioned by internal factors rather than the situation they find themselves in. Dispositionism tends to go hand in hand with a static and often despairing view of people and the way that is "just how they are". It is an excellent method of avoiding difficult problems and situations such as poverty, crime, addiction, and war among others. A dispositionist view of others leaves one vulnerable to fundamental attribution error where situational and environmental factors are underemphasised. The opposite to dispositionism is situationism, also known as please-think-about-this-deeply-for-one-second-longer-you-are-absolutely-ridiculous-in-the-way-you-judge-others-and-not-yourself.

item.title: Ecological crisis
item.description:
Once you learn to read the land, I have no fear of what you will do to it, or with it. And I know many pleasant things it will do to you. Aldo Leopold
Ecology is the study of our dwelling place, more specifically a field of science studying the interconnected systems of Earth.
The ecological crisis is a destabilisation or breakdown of these systems large enough to threaten humanity's continued survival. It is, however, important to include other organisms in this since the ongoing man-made ecological crises are causing the extinction of multiple species every day. From a systems-thinking perspective every species going extinct reduces an ecosystem's options to restabilise after a destabilising event. It is therefore not unlikely that we end up snowballing the effects of climate change by reducing the resilience and complexity of ecosystems past the point where a recovery is possible.
He is happiest, be he king or peasant, who finds peace in his home. Johann Wolfgang von Goethe
Outgoing connections:

Acceleration - The ecological crisis is accelerating and further accelerates many other predicaments towards the precipice.
Access to food - We live off of the benevolence of a functioning global being.
Access to water - When ecosystems collapse, springs dry up and rivers stop singing.
Apathy - It is difficult to truly care about something so immense. Try to initially care about whatever tiny patch of life your heart might skip a beat for.
Avoiding radical options - It appears to be too radical to focus on making sure our planet keeps supporting life.
Biodiversity loss - Ecological collapse and species extinction go hand in hand.
Catastrophic risks - The ecological crisis is without a doubt a catastrophic risk.
Climate change - The relationship between climate change and ecological crisis is recursive, they create and worsen each other.
Dealing with death - How do we stop and acknowledge the life already lost? Maybe the question makes no sense. Would a murderer grieve between his stabbings?
Debt - The debt we've accumulated through our Earth-destroying practices will be passed down through many generations. If we're lucky.
Delusional domination of nature - The lacerations on our backs are from our own whips.
Desertification - Already weakened ecosystems are more vulnerable to the choking sand dunes stretching all around the horizon.
Emotional crisis - How do we respond emotionally to the destruction of our home? How do we allow space for the emotions while avoiding despair?
End of history - No Gaia, no civilisation. No civilisation, no history.
Extreme weather - The more ecosystems degrade, the more likely we are to see spirits go out not with a whimper but with a bang.
Failure to take responsibility - There is no escaping the fact that humans have the power to end all life on Earth. We must learn how to take responsibility, become stewards, control and tame this power.
Fear - Ecological collapse incites fear. It should. We mustn't become paralysed by this fear. If your house is on fire you must get the ones you love to safety and extinguish the flames. The response required is beyond fight, flight, or freeze.
Finite games - Push the Earth far enough in the wrong direction and the game is over.
Genetic modification - Don't worry, if all species die we can simply create new ones. It'll be awesome.
Genocide - People are dying as a result of our ecological crisis. At the same time, we are mostly aware of what actions directly create ecological crises. Awareness of the direct actions we're taking that leads to people dying. Yeah, that's something akin to genocide. Anthropocide?
Greed - The less remains, the more I will fight so that I am the one who gets it.
Greenwashing - The global financial systems will make business opportunities of all available crises.
Hemispherical asymmetry (Earth) - As long as the ecosystems that collapse are somewhere else we're all good. No? One does wonder if anything would change if business and world leaders were forced to live where the collapse was most evident. Then again, most of them currently live in the company of each other on the golf court and I might rather dry into a prune in the desert than play golf with old white men with prunish tans.
Ignorance of interconnectedness - There are no boundaries when it comes to ecosystems. Everything is affected by and affects everything else.
Ignorance of ongoing collapse - We often see ecological collapse as an event ahead of us. It started long ago and is intensively ongoing.
Ignored externalities - The cost of ecologically related externalities is already more than we can ever include but the more obvious this becomes the more skilled businesses will have to be about ignoring them.
Immoral justifications - As the ecological crisis becomes ever more obvious, our justifications for our ways of life become ever more immoral.
Industrial slaughter - Systematic killing of other sentient beings, when explicit, takes the form of slaughterhouses. When implicit it takes the form of global ecological collapse.
Inequality - A global ecological crisis will not affect all beings equally. At least not at first.
Insect loss - The loss of insects and the collapse of ecosystems go together.
Lack of a living world view - If we're killing the world it'll be harder to justify the claim that it's alive. In fact, quite a lot harder.
Lack of balance - In a way, the ecological crisis is one big unbalancing event.
Lack of humility - We haven't yet realised, it seems, that despite our alleged power over nature, we are so ridiculously tiny.
Lack of resilient systems - The complexity of certain ecosystems show a resilience beyond any anthropogenic systems. What took a long time to form, however, is now collapsing rapidly. The more of these systems we lose, the less resilience the global systems have.
Lack of the longterm - Without functioning ecosystems there isn't any longterm to envision.
Lack of time - How can we not see that time is up?
Limits to growth - The ecological crisis worldwide is a clear sign that one cannot grow indefinitely.
Malnutrition - What kills us with the ecological crisis might in the end be starvation.
Mass climate migration - As the global ecological collapse makes itself evident locally there will be massive migrations to the pockets of greenery still alive.
Material extraction - As long as the prevailing systems control us we must increase material extraction while we still can to be on top when we suddenly can't. Or something along those lines...
Meaning crisis - How does one find meaning when one feels like the world is dying?
Mental health - As the roof collapses under the flames the therapist tries to focus on the patient splayed on a chaise long starring absentmindedly at the starless sky, their face vibrant with the light of flame. "I'm not sure what it is but I keep having this OCD-ish need to wash my hands..."
Migration - People will flock towards the few places still supporting life.
Mistreatment of animals - Total extinction of all life is quite clearly mistreatment.
Mistreatment of other humans - Same as the above.
Moloch - Music to Moloch's ears.
Naive progress narrative - Ongoing ecological collapse is one of the main thorns in the progress narrative and is what makes it truly naive.
Pandemics - As ecosystems collapse, humans will not be the only beings trying to scramble for dominance.
Poverty - We might literally lose everything we ever had or ever could have.
Resource conflicts - The ecological crisis will drive resource conflicts as the drowning economy flails wildly.
Solutionism - Each fruit springing out of the sick tree is deformed in a different way and we desperately cling to how to fix each fruit while the tree is allowed to rot away.
Spiritual metacrisis - Where do our souls and the souls of our ancestors go if the Earth splits open and darkness reigns?
The desacration of all places - There is much beauty left but much is being desacrated each second.
The minimisation of all things wild - Ecological crisis is the collapse of the wild.
Tipping points - We might already have reached ecological tippings points.

item.title: Educational crisis
item.description:
Intelligence is the capacity to perceive the essential, the what is; and to awaken this capacity, in oneself and in others, is education. J. Krishnamurti
Education is the transmission of knowledge, skills and traits and means to bring forth. A crisis of education is therefore the potential or actual failure of this transmission and the failure to bring forth humans with the knowledge, skills, and traits needed to find their way in the world. Informal education's role has decreased while the increased role of formal education has narrowed to the point where much necessary knowledge and understanding requires an unlearning of one's formal education. Education, both formal and informal, is necessary for the prevailing of cultures but its current effects aren't just decreasingly constructive, they're also increasingly destructive.
Our care of the child should be governed, not by the desire to make him learn things, but by the endeavor always to keep burning within him that light which is called intelligence. Maria Montessori

item.title: Emotional crisis
item.description:

An emotional crisis is a state in which we are stirred up and agitated, internally and externally, to the extent that we lose control over our emotions and consequently the behaviours they might entail. item.title: End of history
item.description:
It is not unlikely that our lives will fill the last pages of the short book of the history of our human civilisation. What does it mean to be at the end of history? Well, at the very least it means that we are at the dissolution of a certain narrative that has been constant throughout human civilisation, the narrative of progress and ascent. We will either reach the pinnacle of this progress curve, something I believe we have already failed to do, or this narrative and its resulting manifestations will collapse, something I believe it has already started to do.
In the words of John Milbank "we are not so much subject to passing tensions, potentially resolvable, as to the ultimate emergence of tensions latent in the very foundations of the modern". The dynamics that got us to this point, that created our progress, are the same dynamics which create our downfall. Therefore, we must either redesign and rebuild our foundations or watch it all crumble. One of our most complicated problems is that we have built so many unsteady structures on top of this rotting foundation that it looks to be impossible to even approach the foundation without risking a complete collapse.
No matter what we do or where we go, we are at the end of history.

item.title: Exponential technology
item.description:
Exponential technologies are technologies that in one way or another follow an exponential path. This behaviour can be due to a technology that spreads exponentially across domains, grows exponentially in use, exhibits exponential intrinsic behaviour, requires exponential energy, or sees exponential progress in its own development. The number of real and potentially exponential technologies has increased with the invention of the computer. Whereas the expanding use of the steam engine required physical parts and specific knowledge, information through software travels at the speed of light. Humans lack intuition for exponential behaviours and care must be taken for us to not invent and develop our own doom. How to wisely handle exponential technologies is possibly one of our most difficult predicaments.

item.title: Extreme weather
item.description:
Extreme weather is any weather condition at the extremes of whatever has been observed and recorded in the past and includes heat waves, cold waves, storms, etc.
The IPCC Sixth Assessment Report defines an extreme weather event as "an event that is rare at a particular place and time of year. Definitions of 'rare' vary, but an extreme weather event would normally be as rare as or rarer than the 10th or 90th percentile of a probability density function estimated from observations."
Human activity is most likely the main driver of the increased frequency of extreme weather events.
Extreme weather can also act as warnings and omens. Will we listen?
A tree with strong roots can withstand the most violent storm, but the tree can't grow roots just as the storm appears on the horizon.. Dalai Lama

item.title: Failure to take responsibility
item.description:
How are we failing to take responsibility? Why should we be held accountable for our actions at all? Having responsibility is having an obligation to respond for what one has done. Every externally affecting action, which means all actions, should come with a promise back to the source of that action. Since we live in endlessly complex and intricate webs of causality in the modern world it is increasingly difficult to take responsibility and to even know and understand what to take responsibility for. How should you be responsible for the emissions of the airplane you're travelling in? What about the food served on the plane, the titanium alloys used in manufacturing it, the noise of the engines, the price of your ticket contributing to the continuing unquestioned existence of airlines, etc. There is a blurry line here. When you cross this line you enter the infinite fields of karmic complexity. Karmic complexity does not necessarily belong in this predicament.
Largely, I believe the responsibility for many predicaments comes down, not to individuals, but institutions, corporations, and, most of all, human-created systems. As long as our systems fail to take responsibility for their externalities we will not manage this landscape. To be even more concrete, this isn't even a question of nuance and detail, it can be as simple as taking responsibility for one's own shit, literally and figuratively.

item.title: Faulty meta-optimisation
item.description:
Meta-optimisation is optimising what you're optimising. In simpler terms, it is prioritisation. Every action we take can be seen as contributing to one long optimisation equation, consciously or not. There are times when what you optimise for is obvious, perhaps buying a car that maximises convenience while minimising cost. Most times, however, what you're optimising for is complicated and multi-faceted. Furthermore, many systems incentivise us to optimise badly. This is where meta-optimisation comes in. How do you make sure that if you want to optimise for a "life well lived", you have (meta)optimised your optimisation equation to actually yield that result? Now, this is an unanswerable question or, rather, it is a question you can spend several lives trying to answer, but while the perfect optimisation doesn't exist and constantly changes it is quite clear when an optimisation equation hasn't been correctly (meta)optimised. When this fact appears in stark relief, something has to change. When variables such as wealth keep increasing while variables such as time spent in old-growth forests (apologies to any hippiephobe), enjoyment of music, or pure joy have stopped increasing and may even be decreasing we have to re-meta-optimise.
Lastly, there is of course also the question of meta-meta-optimisation and meta-meta-meta-optimisation but that becomes a bit too meta at this time, even for me.
