item.title: Fear
item.description:
Fear is an intensely unpleasant primal emotion in response to perceiving or recognising a danger or threat and commonly leads to fight-or-flight reactions of different degrees. Importantly, thought influences our perception of what is or isn't a threat and our thoughts are further influenced by everything and everyone around us. Our complex modern surroundings lead to threats and dangers being less clear than in the primitive setting, where fear evolved, and therefore risks fear and its reactive behaviours becoming less congruent with reality. Another important note is that fear itself is rarely the problem. It is rather our perception of the world that can get muddied and generate fear where none is reasonable and vice versa. This is especially true when votes and wealth can be gained through instilling fear in others.

item.title: Finite games
item.description:
There are, according to James Carse, two kinds of games. Finite games are played for the purpose of winning and infinite games for the purpose of continuing the play. An infinite game can contain one or more finite games, a finite game cannot contain an infinite game. Modernity has chosen to exclusively focus on finite games. Finite games keeps us wrongly competitive, static, hostile, individualist, tribal, polarised, suspicious, miserable, and blindly heading for destruction. Infinite games lead us to be cooperative, dynamic, open, inclusive, ever-changing, engaged, and adaptive to whatever may come our way.
Life is an infinite game filled with finite games. James Carse again: "Although it may be evident enough in theory that whoever plays a finite game plays freely, it is often the case that finite players will be unaware of this absolute freedom and will come to think that whatever they do they must do". How much in your life feels like a decision taken for you, something you must do?
Let us say that where the finite player plays to be powerful the infinite player plays with strength. A powerful person is one who brings the past to an outcome, settling all its unresolved issues. A strong person is one who carries the past into the future, showing that none of its issues is capable of resolution. James Carse, Finite & Infinite Games

item.title: Genocide
item.description:
Genocide is the intentional destruction of a people. People, cultures, and traditions whose voices must be silenced for the greater good of modernity have two options. Assimilate and forget or be annihilated. There are very few peoples left to annihilate but many, perhaps most, contemporary military conflicts have genocidal traits.

Centralisation - In the end we may be one people remaining, united and miserable.
Colonialist narratives - Colonialism and genocide are good friends.
Failure to take responsibility - Taking responsibility for those who are dead because of us isn't easy. It's not impossible though. Just inconvenient.
Finite games - Play to win. The monks of Tibet might've managed to escape the wheel of samsara but they didn't escape the raining bullets.
Hobbesian views - Since, by definition, those who commit genocide are the survivors they will and they must further the views that those who were killed were primitive savages very different from themselves, from us who remain.
Illusion of no option - Many genocides are justified through a manufactured narrative of having no other option.
Immoral justifications - No justification for genocide is just.
Language - How important is the relation to the killing of languages? Languages allow us to think differently and communicate these thoughts differently. How impactful has our history of linguicide and glottophagy been for our present predicaments?
Loss of cultural complexity - Graveyards of complexity will stare at the demise of us remaining simpletons.
Madness of safety - Better to remove any and all risks.
Maximum power principle - Never allow a different people to even come close to acquiring power equal to yours. Smite them down as soon as they start climbing.
Migration - Sadly, it is often impossible to escape the extinction of one's own people.
Mistreatment of other humans - Believe it or not, genocide is on the side of the spectrum labelled not-so-nice.
Modern slavery - Sometimes, the people being killed have an option for escape. Slavery. Perhaps not explicitly. But still.

Polarisation - Interestingly, at this time of ongoing crises, we suddenly have a split in Western societies where it seems people have two sides to choose from: hate jews or hate arabs. Convenient distraction, I'd say.
Propaganda - The propagation of the winners' agenda must continue.
Violence - Genocide and its justifications will further increase the use of violence to solve problems.
War - Genocide is war. War is often genocide. Though, when the jews were killed in gas chambers... What kind of war stops one side from fighting back? I take it back, genocide is not war. But wars are often started because of committed or desired genocides.

item.title: Healthcare
item.description:
Calm down, hear me out. Modern healthcare is, in many ways, rightfully placed at the top of modern human achievement. There are about a billion asterisks to this statement, mainly consisting of arguments about the failure of accepting illness, suffering, pain, and death as well as iatrogenic diseases etc... But nonetheless, modern healthcare might be a reason why I can write this and why you can read it. So what's the problem, or rather, what's the predicament in modern healthcare? Once again, it is an issue with balance, optimisation, and the exclusion of non-quantifiable aspects of health. Let's look at an example.
Healthcare in Sweden is absolutely atrocious and also completely incredible. On the one side, for most health issues you will be met with different medical doctors each appointment, most of them only having a few stressful minutes to half-listen before sending you on your way without too much hassle and effort. Meeting human to human, trusting expertise, being listened to, finding help for mental health issues, being taken seriously, all of this is a rarity in healthcare. However, prove that your condition is serious enough and nurses, doctors, surgeons, therapists, priests, and, I'm sure, the prime minister, suddenly spawn out of nowhere and you're sent through a mechanistic wonder of expertise, reason, intuition, skill, efficiency, medical substances, all in order for you to come out the other side healthy and alive, barely paying a dime for it. There is something to this. Is it modernity excelling at treating sickness while being almost incapacitated with regards to health and a good life? Also, what roles do medications, something medical corporations profit from, play in the maintaining but not curing of a population? There is something to this. We have somehow gotten healthcare very wrong while getting parts of it very right. Why? Also, the way we tackle curing cancers never seems to include a conversation about halting the release of anthropogenic carcinogens? Why? Can we get healthcare right if we get everything else wrong?

item.title: Hedonism
item.description:
The search for pleasure is circular, repetitive, atemporal. The variety seeking of the spectator, the thrill hunter, the sexually promiscuous, always ends in the same place. It has an end. It comes to the end and has to start over. It is not a journey and return, but a closed cycle, a locked room, a cell. Ursula K. Le Guin
Hedonism refers to the prioritisation of pleasure in one's life, perhaps even the prioritisation of pleasure above anything else. It can and often does include different types of pleasure, from the more obvious sensory pleasures to intellectual, emotional, and spiritual pleasures. Hedonism in and of itself isn't a particularly troublesome predicament, if it is one at all, but rather, it becomes one when, as with many other predicaments, it is increased in scale and prioritised beyond proportion and balance. A life without pleasure, a condition commonly called anhedonia, is not to be desired but a life that only hunts for pleasure tends to create one-marshmallow solutions and longer term displeasure, at least within the current cultural control systems.

item.title: Hemispherical asymmetry (Brain)
item.description:
In the words of Iain McGilchrist, the natural philosopher, scientist, and author of The Matter With Things:
I believe that nowadays we live no longer in the presence of the world, but rather in a re-presentation of it. The significance of that is that the left hemisphere’s task is to ‘re-present’ what first ‘presences’ to the right hemisphere. This re-presentation has all the qualities of a virtual image: an infinitely thin, immobile, fragment of a vast, seamless, living, ever-flowing whole. From a standpoint within the representation, everything is reversed. Instead of seeing what is truly present as primary, and the representation as a necessarily diminished derivative of it, we see reality as merely a special case of our representation – one in which something is added in to ‘animate’ it. In this it is like a ciné film that consists of countless static slices requiring a projector to bring it back into what at least looks to us like a living flow. On the contrary, however, reality is not an animated version of our re-presentation of it, but our re-presentation a devitalised version of reality. It is the re-presentation that is a special, wholly atypical and imaginary, case of what is truly present, as the filmstrip is of life – the re-presentation is simply what one might call the ‘limit case’ of what is real. Stepping out of this world-picture and into the world, stepping out of suspended animation and back into life, will involve inverting many of our perhaps cherished assumptions. Iain McGilchrist, The Matter With Things
McGilchrist makes the case that the major underlying dynamic behind the issues of modernity lies in the left hemisphere having become the master of the right, rather than the right being master of the left. Both hemispheres and, more generally, all facets of the human mind are vital to our survival and becoming as living beings, but when our narrow representations of reality get to rule the living world we are in deep trouble.

item.title: Hobbesian views
item.description:
Humans are at their core mechanistic. Left to their own devices they would live in a war of all against all, completely lacking industry, culture, knowledge, art, literature, society, and instead live in a constant state of fear and danger of violent death. A solitary, poor, nasty, brutish, and short life. According to Thomas Hobbes that is. Humans need to be controlled through a social contract and a civil society with one sovereign authority in control of everything in order to protect them, he continues.
There are surely some truths to be found in Hobbes' theories of moral and political philosophy, especially with regards to a machine constructed by human beings that somehow controls them more than they control it. Nevertheless, Hobbesian views will most likely lead to the creation of the very mechanistic creatures it wants to control. How we see determines what we see.

item.title: Hyperstimuli
item.description:
Hyperstimuli, or supernormal stimuli, are exaggerated versions of a stimulus that elicits a response more strongly than the stimulus for which it evolved or an artificial version of a stimulus eliciting the same response but lacking the commonly related substance.
Junk food, pornography, media, travel, advertisements, AI-generated content, etc can all be classified as hyperstimuli. Hyperstimuli make us crave the artificial while being disastrous for mental health and the overall development of societies with well-functioning humans. We have developed strong responses to specific stimuli based on what these stimuli tend to give us. Sugar and fat tends to be coupled with nutritious food and has historically required much work to acquire, sex tends to be coupled with intimacy and a strengthening of social bonds. Refined sugar gives us the dopaminergic response without either the nutritional reward or the required work. Pornography gives us the physical response we get from sex without the intimacy.

item.title: Ignorance of ongoing collapse
item.description:
And one day, too late, your principles, if you were ever sensible of them, all rush in upon you. The burden of self-deception has grown too heavy, and some minor incident, in my case my little boy, hardly more than a baby, saying ‘Jewish swine,’ collapses it all at once, and you see that everything, everything, has changed and changed completely under your nose. The world you live in—your nation, your people—is not the world you were born in at all. The forms are all there, all untouched, all reassuring, the houses, the shops, the jobs, the mealtimes, the visits, the concerts, the cinema, the holidays. But the spirit, which you never noticed because you made the lifelong mistake of identifying it with the forms, is changed. Now you live in a world of hate and fear, and the people who hate and fear do not even know it themselves; when everyone is transformed, no one is transformed. Now you live in a system which rules without responsibility even to God. The system itself could not have intended this in the beginning, but in order to sustain itself it was compelled to go all the way. Milton Sanford Mayer
Imagine, for a moment, that we suddenly were able to manage all of the predicaments in the landscape, that we somehow solved all of our problems and helped the Earth recover. The time preceding this moment will, I believe, be seen as one of the most catastrophic collapses of life the Earth has ever seen. In just a few hundred years the Earth has gone from a beautiful, wild, and diverse place to a planet where more than 95% of mammals are cattle bred for food, pets bred for obedience, and humans pushed to compliance. The Earth is, of course, still beautiful and diverse, and has some wildness left. My argument is simply that so much has already collapsed and is already collapsing, the collapse is not some future event. The same goes for the economy, the climate, ecosystems, social welfare, spirituality, and life force in general. It is already happening, how do we control the descent, save what can be saved, and work on recovering and cultivating, fermenting, something better in the ruins?
The collapse is already here. It's just not evenly distributed.

item.title: Ignorance of the mystical
item.description:
The mystical rejects definition. However, were I to give the modern use of the word a definition I might define it as anything within or outside of science that rejects explanation and to which there doesn't seem to be a logical path. Being ignorant of the mystical therefore traps us within the strict logical boundaries of science and, slowly but surely, mystical experiences will recede from our consciousness.
More concretely, take an example, you are experiencing a sunset with everything that moment can include. Even if you try to explain the external event through physics and astronomy, or the internal "cogs" of your body and mind through simple chemical, mechanistic models of explanation, there is an infinity, an endlessness, in all moments of life. Even if you buy into the chemical explanation of the mind, isn't then that in itself mysterious and powerful? The alterings, inhibitions, or excitations of a few chemicals can make you love another human and protect them with your life. We must stay open towards the mystical rather than closing ourselves away from it. If we are to have any chance of living it is within the mystical we will find the path onward.
The storyteller weaves the mysterious into the fabric of life, lacing it with the comic, the tragic, the obscene, making safe paths through dangerous territory. Dougald Hine & Paul Kingsnorth, Dark Mountain Manifesto

item.title: Illusion of competence
item.description:
While having coffee with a friend of mine, a PhD in economic history, he told me about a way one of his professors had explained the complexity of economics and causality. The professor asked my friend to imagine a room filled with crisscrossing ropes and trusses, creating a massive spider web of ropes in all directions. When you pulled one rope several other ropes would move in unexpected strange ways and if told to move a select few ropes in a certain way something always seemed to ruin it. Modern civilisation has remained seated in a small room with closed windows and doors, feeling competent in what to pull, completely ignorant of the fact that all ropes reach out through cracks in the walls, floor, and ceiling. Yet we sit there pulling and pulling and everything, well, everything seems great.
To be competent is to have the ability to do something well or efficiently. We, the people of modern civilisation, are extremely competent at believing we're competent when we're not. We are the least competent and the most helpless version of humans the earth has seen.

item.title: Illusion of GDP decoupling
item.description:
GDP decoupling tends to, in general, mean the decoupling of GDP (or growth) from carbon emissions. Taking a broader view would mean decoupling GDP from any long-term detrimental externalities. Taking an even broader view could mean increasing global welfare without increasing long-term detrimental externalities and, despite the predicament's title, this is not an unreasonable goal for humanity to have for the coming years, ideally maintaining or increasing welfare while decreasing externalities. Now that is an impressive optimisation challenge if I've ever seen one.
It's easier to imagine the end of the world than the end of capitalism. Mark Fisher

item.title: Illusion of no option
item.description:
...humans live and act in ways as fish live and act in water. We don’t notice in how many ways we depend on ways. Being in a sea of ways is being human. Chuang Tzu
The illusion of no option means a false belief that there are no other ways but the current way of doing things. So called capitalist realism is a type of illusion of no option which says that there are no functioning economic systems besides capitalism. We have no choice but to grow, extract, fight, use violence, use fossil fuels, be profitable, hire more scrum masters, enforce national borders, eat meat, use generative AI, earn money to pay rent, travel, invest, participate, and the list could go on forever. We live in a world structured by models and systems created by humans and these can, whether it appears that way or not, be changed.

item.title: Illusion of understanding
item.description:
Explanation is a well-dressed error. Julio Cortázar, Hopscotch
True understanding cannot be explained or boiled down to concepts or models. True understanding and the understanding of truths lies beyond the verbal and explainable and modern civilisation is, unfortunately, unknowingly, constantly conflating explanations with understanding. As a predicament, the illusion of understanding presents us with a world that never makes real sense with the explanations we have, it doesn't behave the way we expect or want. In short, everything is infinitely more complex than we can know and, since it is comforting and often useful to place the world within the frames of concepts, models, principles, and laws, we end up with an illusion of understanding the world, missing that it stretches outside of the frames, endlessly in all directions.

item.title: Immoral justifications
item.description:
Justification is the act of showing something to be right or proper. Morals are principles concerning right and proper behaviour of humans in society. The paradox of modernity with its notions of progress largely stems from our uncanny ability to justify our improper actions, both to others but maybe more so to ourselves. Our justifications of moral are quite immoral. We need this immoral veneer of justifications to separate and protect us from the higher order effects of our needs and consequent actions, in order to believe that we are good people when, in reality, we might, mostly unwillingly and unknowingly, be eons away from the civilised saintliness we imagine.

item.title: Industrial slaughter
item.description:
We are definitely different from the bad people in history. The immoral fools tricked by Hitler into saluting the iron cross and casting their votes in favour of genocide, the spiritually corrupt slave traders of the colonies in Africa, the Europeans pillaging and raping (culturally and literally) the indigenous people of the "new worlds" of America, Australia, etc; the brilliant geniuses talked into developing the atom bomb, the monsters who then dropped those bombs over Japan in the name of peace. We are definitely different from them. The most efficient systematic slaughter of sentient beings the planet has ever seen, the complete indifference to the ecocide required for our day-to-day lives, the endless belief in infinite growth on a finite planet, the quantification of all that is sacred into mere resources and business opportunities, the utter carelessness toward the world our children will inherit. All this we manage to stand for in the name of progress and human kind's superiority over all others. No, we are definitely different. We are worse.
Industrial slaughter is the efficient industrialised process of killing other beings. Rarely can the slaughterhouses of modernity be heard, hidden away in fields far from people, but, if you listen, you can hear them.z
Outgoing connections:

Access to food - Industrial slaughter funnels energy and nutrients upward in the chain, leading to a horribly inefficient way of extracting energy. True, we might not want to eat exclusively genetically modified soy beans (neither do the animals) but the conversion of arable land to food ready to be eaten in the form of meat decreases people's direct access to food.
Access to water - Producing 1kg of animal protein requires about 100 times more water than producing 1 kg of grain protein. There are populations dying of thirst while others feast on beef.
Agriculture - Industrial slaughter is the main driver and shaper of modern agriculture.
Ancient sunlight, old sunlight, current sunlight - With industrial slaughter we are using up all ancient sunlight and cutting down old sunlight simply to inefficiently extract current sunlight for what? The taste of defeat?
Animal views - Beef, poultry, pork. Not cows, chickens, pigs. Lives become products in a machine. Hey, you, just a little business idea. Take it and run with it if you want to. Listen. Make one of those toys with buttons in the shape of chickens, cows, dogs, etc where, if you push a button, it makes the sound of the animal. But just have every click of a button emit a terrible scream for mercy. Test these toys at kindergartens and iterate your design process until you've reached perfection.
Apathy - How does one care for lives lived in dense darkness only seen as packaged products in brightly bluelit grocery stores?
Avoiding radical options - Not eat meat? What, and become a fucking faggot soyboy?
Biodiversity loss - We're extincting species every day while increasing the populations of a select few productive friends of civilisation.
Breakdown of information infrastructure - Make it obligatory that slaughterhouses are built with paper thin walls as close to the city centres as possible.
Capitalism - Fat CEOs munching on the marinated ass cheeks of piglets. Ah, such dignified lives we live.
Climate change - Drastically reducing or eliminating industrial slaughter will be necessary to properly manage and/or avoid disasters following climate change.
Cognitive dissonance - A cow is not much different from a dog. A dog is not much different from you. Cognitive dissonance is a powerful weapon against acts of love.
Dealing with death - There is a longer discussion to be had regarding meat eating and dealing with death. That discussion is better had somewhere else since it doesn't apply to industrial scale killing. We must acquire the ability to internalise the deaths and suffering casued by the meat industry. To do that and not drown is difficult. Difficult but necessary. What else can we do? Where else do we think we must go?
Debt - How could we ever begin to repay this debt?
Deforestation - For example, over 70% of Brazil's deforestation of the Amazon rainforest is driven by cattle ranching.
Delusional domination of nature - Look out over the world. For all our power, can you see how small we are, how truly powerless we are, keeping not a grain of dignity while only destroying our own inner nature, left with sterile salt flats.
Despair - An existence forcedly placed upon billions of rotting animal carcasses. How can I not despair? If humanity hangs, may it hang with its tippy toes just touching the ground. What sound does a human make? One of despair.
Ecological crisis - Industrial slaughter contributes to our current ecological crises in several ways. Maybe most obviously by replacing living ecosystems with monocultural factories of death.
Educational crisis - Society does its best to keep the truth about slaughter away from most children. I remember visiting a farm with the purpose of learning about raising cattle for meat and milk yet I never got to take a newborn calf from its mother nor shoot it between the eyes and roast it. To be fair, I wouldn't have wanted to. But there is a massive educational chasm between knowing the truth and knowing the terror. Can we at least strive for truth?
Emotional crisis - It becomes emotionally difficult to walk around with the awareness of the incessantly ongoing systematic holocausts.
Energy consumption increasing - We are consuming more and ever more, and meat consumption stemming from the expansion of industrial slaughter globally, when it should decrease or fully cease, is only increasing.
Energy - Industrial slaughter and its energy-related implications clearly illustrate the inefficiency of our efficiency.
Failure to take responsibility - We must and we will be held responsible for the unnecessary suffering and deaths we've caused.
Genetic modification - We keep optimising our systems of energy extraction. One way is through genetically modifying crops and cattle for productivity.
Global supply chains - Planted salmon harvested in Norway, sent to China for processing, packaged as fish sticks in America. Glorious.
Healthcare - What fraction of our health problems come from eating the flesh of animals in distress?
Hedonism - On the train up to Gothenburg I sat next to a group of middle-aged IT-consultants who were heading to a company team building event (yeah, I know...). For three hours all they spoke about was different kinds of beer and different kinds of meat they had consumed. Sad sedentary satires of a viking past, flattened hemorrhoids and pale hairless bellies with crusty navels. Pinnacle of modern masculinity.
Hemispherical asymmetry (Brain) - The left hemisphere sees beings as inanimate, machines, automatons. If they scream they scream because they're programmed to do so. Industrial slaughter, then, simply becomes a machine that disassembles machines to then extract those parts deemed useful to us, the most important machines.
Illusion of competence - I read an article the other day. It discussed some novel research in the fields of AI and organic pig farms. After ten years of analysing the sounds of the pigs through advanced AI models the researchers were surprised to learn that even on organic farms the pigs seemed quite stressed. Funny that. I wonder how many years we'd have to study Hebrew to learn that jews exterminated with organic Zyklon B would be quite stressed as well.
Illusion of no option - We have to eat a lot of meat. Just look at all of us, how fit, ripped, and healthy we all are. To keep that going I need my one chicken per day minimum.
Inequality - First of all there is an inequality in terms of the value of the lives of other animals. Secondly, there is the fact that the Western diet consists of so much meat that it's impossible for the rest of the world to match it.
Insect loss - Industrial slaughter and its many requirements being prioritised over other factors is contributing to insect loss.
Lack of quiet spaces - I can hear them everywhere. It is never quiet. Can you?
Limits to growth - For everyone to eat the amount of meat the average Westerner does we would need more than one Earth.
Malnutrition - Over 2 billion people are at risk of malnutrition due to food insecurity. Feeding half the world's grain crop to animals raised for meat, eggs, and milk instead of directly to humans is a significant waste of natural resources, including fossil fuels, water, and land.
Meat eating - If industrial slaughter disappeared we would drastically reduce our meat consumption, not just out of necessity but from lack of convenience and the reality of it all surfacing.
Mental health - You are what you eat. Trapped, flightless, working beasts of burden, teats swollen, cocks cut off, drooling, terrified, thank God it's kosher.
Mistreatment of animals - Yeah, eh, yep.
Moloch - Moloch thrives best floating in the lee behind the syrupy waves of their ocean of blood.
Monocultures (agriculture) - Efficiency, streamlining, simplifying, optimising, maximising.
Net negative caloric extraction - Every step upward in the nutrition chain loses energy. The only moral responsiblity we have is to learn how to photosynthesise. Or just eat plants. Whatever works for you.
Obesity - I do wonder what fraction of obese people are vegetarian... Industrial slaughter makes meat cheap and available for all. And for those who react to this by saying "but, but, but carbs!". Yeah, yeah, go listen to Joe Rogan or something.
Pandemics - Distressed animals tightly packed is perfect for the spreading of bacteria and viruses.
Populations entering the 'middle class' - I suppose being middle class means being able to travel and have bacon for breakfast.
Profit - Industrial slaughter wouldn't be a thing if it wasn't massively profitable.
Sameness - There will be animals all over the world and they will all look the same.
Spiritual metacrisis - You can't be animistic and run industrial slaughterhouses.
Violence - Systematised violence.

item.title: Ineffective institutions
item.description:
Why are institutions failing to manage our predicaments? Their existence has been made possible through many of the same mechanisms that have spawned the predicaments in the first place, meaning their only possible actions are within the dominating systems. Since the institutions must work within the boundaries of the systems they lack the ability to change the systems. As long as our institutions have obligations to serve specific economic and political interests there will not be any systemic change that allows for the effective management of our predicaments.
How are we to avoid those in office becoming deeply corrupt when everything is devoid of meaning? Franz Kafka, The Trial

item.title: Inequality
item.description:
Inequality is, clearly, the negation of equality, which means something which is equal to, or the same as, something else. Inequality is then when something isn't the same as something else. It is only when we're treated the same that we're allowed our differences.
The modern, highly praised version of equality is the inclusion of everyone in the eternal climb to be better than others. A woman shouldn't be at home caring for children, mending clothes and cooking, rather, she should strive for the wealth and status that enables her to give that opportunity to someone further down the ladder, how generous of her. Inequality has been solved by making everyone equally inequal in one single hierarchical structure. However, even the equality of inequality is inequal since the ladder was built by and for white male hands and, furthermore, the higher up you are the easier it is to climb. Whoops. Oh well, nothing we can do about it now! Look at the cute poor blackies down there, they look like tiny little ants, oh, one just fell, how funny, Charles, did you see that, we should get one of those, they look so lively, full of vigour, bless them.

item.title: Inertia
item.description:
Inertia is the tendency of objects in motion to stay in motion and objects at rest to stay at rest. As a predicament, inertia is the unbudging nature of the trendlines and modes of being of modern civilisation. Through energy extraction and economic growth we've accelerated to such speeds that we seem unable to slow down and, if the engine was to stop, our inertia would keep us heading straight for the precipice. Inertia presents us with the fact that it wouldn't be enough to stop our negatively impacting actions, we would have to actively reverse their effects or prepare to recover from the crash. A controlled descent, a hospicing of modernity.

item.title: Information isn't knowledge
item.description:
Information can give form to thought and be part of the process of acquiring knowledge but it is, undeniably, not knowledge. The relationship between information and knowledge can be likened to the one between vision and seeing. Not all who have vision truly see. Another metaphor is that of information as bricks and knowledge as a built structure. Treating information as if it was equal to knowledge can result in an overreliance on data, bad decision-making, lack of adaptive behaviour, overconfidence, illusion of understanding, lack of a broader perception, bad predictions, false beliefs, and more. Information is also external whereas knowledge is something deeply internal and this, importantly, is what makes information so easily transferable compared to knowledge. Information is neutral whereas knowledge can come with judgement, suitable action, awareness, purpose, and understanding. Beware of the need to "stay informed" as it can often mean rejecting the time and space needed for the forming of knowledge.
Nothing happened today. And if anything did, I’d rather not talk about it, because I didn’t understand it. Roberto Bolaño

item.title: Insect loss
item.description:
Why should we tolerate a diet of weak poisons, a home in insipid surroundings, a circle of acquaintances who are not quite our enemies, the noise of motors with just enough relief to prevent insanity? Who would want to live in a world which is just not quite fatal? Rachel Carson, Silent Spring
Insects make up 90% of all animal species on Earth and are crucial parts of all ecosystems with pollinators being particularly important for the food supply for other animals and humans. Insect decline is a complex area to study and estimates on the rate of decline vary in different localities. A 2020 meta-analysis estimated a decline rate of 9% per decade for terrestrial insects but, notably, an increase in freshwater insects of 11% per decade. Most research, however, show declines in insects globally.
A March 2019 statement by the Entomological Society of America said there was not yet sufficient data to predict an imminent mass extinction of insects and that some of the extrapolated predictions might "have been extended well past the limits of the data or have been otherwise over-hyped"
I wonder what to make of the quote above. Data can always be misleading but if we are actually risking a mass extinction of insects I don't see how taking that seriously is over-hyping. If what we need before we decide to change current trends is "sufficient data" to be collected then we really are fucked.
We urgently need an end to these false assurances, to the sugar coating of unpalatable facts. It is the public that is being asked to assume the risks that the insect controllers calculate. The public must decide whether it wishes to continue on the present road, and it can do so only when in full possession of the facts. Rachel Carson, Silent Spring
Outgoing connections:

Acceleration - Things might happen quite quickly if the droning hum of spring flowers is no longer accompanied by buzzing of bees.
Access to food - No pollination, no food. Mostly.
Biased evidence selection - Well, actually, where I live there seem to be a lot of mosquitoes nowadays. What do you say to that, huh?
Biodiversity loss - Insects make up an enormous part of the species of the planet and support most other species.
Catastrophic risks - It might sound like an exaggeration but if we suddenly lack the necessary amount of pollinators to keep our food production up we are well and truly fucked.
Complexity mismatch - With a reduction of insects we have a heavily reduced natural complexity.
Delusional domination of nature - Well, I mean... To be fair, we appear to be quite good at developing working insecticides. Go humans.
Ecological crisis - Insect loss is a massive part of the global ecological crisis.
Ignorance of ongoing collapse - Even if we halted insect loss today there would most likely need to be active initiatives to restabilise and reintroduce insect populations.
Ignoring diversity - Those who claim we aren't actually reducing the total amount of insects seem to be in a rut of quantification where a million honey bees are equal to a million different bee species. Diversity matters. More honey bees are not the solution.
Naive techno-optimism - Maybe we can just replace insects with tiny drones or something? Oh, great... I swear, we'll invent mosquitobots to make it feel like we're really in nature before we do anything about insect loss.
Over-reliance on technology - The more we lose of the natural systems aiding in activities like food production, the more reliant we become on high-tech solutions to "save" us, or at least kick the bucket further down the road.
The minimisation of all things wild - Most wild places are filled with crawling, buzzing, and flying.
Tipping points - How long until insect populations collapse completely? And what follows from such a collapse?

item.title: Investing
item.description:
An investment is the commitment of resources to achieve later benefits. There are many types of investments such as stocks, bonds, cash, real estate, loans, cryptocurrencies, and more. Investments must include the notion of ownership and for an investment to be successful it usually means that either you won and someone else lost (zero-sum) or whatever area you invested in grew financially. Another important point is that any investment into something is an action that tries to shape the world, meaning that whatever is invested in will be pushed to succeed while whatever isn't invested in will be ignored. Dressing parts of the future in your own colours makes you wonder what future generations will think of the ruins covered in our tattered robes.

item.title: Jevons paradox
item.description:
In economics, the Jevons paradox occurs when technological progress increases the efficiency with which a resource is used, but the falling cost of use induces increases in demand enough that resource use is increased, rather than reduced. This was originally related to the efficiency and increase in coal use. As technology improves energy efficiency we end up using more rather than less of the resource required for the activity. There is, in other words, always an important nuance to any discussion related to technological advances that promise increased efficiency in that they potentially worsen the problem they claim to solve.

item.title: Knowledge isn't wisdom
item.description:
One can know a lot and wholly lack wisdom. Some might sneer at the notion of wisdom, comparing the high seat of knowledge that modern science and reasoning is built upon with the purported "wisdom" of primitive dead peoples. Rest assured that wisdom lies above knowledge as wisdom entails the direction of action based on knowledge, experience, understanding, and insight. Knowledge tells us nothing of what to do or why. It is, rather, an awareness of certain stated facts, models, concepts, principles, or explanations. Don't get me wrong, knowledge is of the utmost importance but it is nothing without wisdom. The two should never be confused.

item.title: Lack of a living world view
item.description:
The fate of our times is characterized by rationalization and intellectualization and, above all, by the disenchantment of the world. Max Weber
The view of the world as dead, inanimate, and mechanistic is not particularly congruent with the synergistic, self-regulating, and complex nature of the world as it presents itself to our lived experience. However, this view makes it easier to justify manipulating its parts. Strapping the plow on the oxen both makes it into, and requires the oxen to be seen as, nothing but a machine. Further, if we see the world as inanimate then our actions cannot kill it because it never lived in the first place. The world is not a collection of dead static things, it is an endless ocean of living flowing streams.

item.title: Lack of agency
item.description:
How wonderful it is that nobody needs to wait a single moment before starting to improve the world. Anne Frank
Agency is the capacity to act, to effectively set in motion, powerfully incite action. From the smallest scale of single human decisions to decisions on planetary scale, we often seem to lack agency or, at the very least, lack a belief in our agency. Agency is also, more specifically, the capacity to do something differently from, or in addition to, the events that simply happen to you. It is, in other words, independent from the direct context and events of your situation. You can always increase your agency in some way, find how and where you're capable of action.
If nothing else, learning to accept situations where you experience a lack of agency can lead to an internal agency of thought that suddenly changes everything. There are no moments that completely lack agency, you just have to notice it.

item.title: Lack of belonging
item.description:
Do you belong somewhere? Do the birds miss you when they leave before the leaves change? Do the fields wonder where your footprints strayed when you're away? Is the moonlight in search of your shadow when you're gone? Does the sun rise hesitatingly, wonder whether to start the day before you've arrived?
Few of us modern humans can imagine the feeling of belonging that has dominated most of our species' history, I sure can't. Sometimes I feel a hint of it, like a drop of brackish water on the tip of my tongue, promising an ocean of eternal belonging somewhere beyond the archipelago.
We, as humans, require our people, our place, and a clarity of our role in it all. Most importantly, away from all abstraction, we require a feeling of belonging.

item.title: Lack of cultural control systems
item.description:
Wisdom, spirituality, animism, and elders have contributed historically to creating cultural control systems which, as opposed to laws, control behaviours with an open hand. Modernity mostly lacks cultural control systems since they have been replaced by game theory. When people mention the need for religion, "a new christianity", or a complete destruction of capitalism, I believe the foundational discussion that must be had is one of cultural control systems in general. A faulty control system will lead to complete lack of cultural balance, an absence of any control system whatsoever is unbounded chaos.

item.title: Lack of dark spaces
item.description:
Work stops at sunset. Darkness falls over the building site. The sky is filled with stars. "There is the blueprint," they say. Italo Calvino, Invisible Cities
I wonder how common it is in the history of humans to feel safer at night when the stars aren't visible. Somehow, I sense an obvious issue in that the more we brighten the darkness, the more threatening the darkness becomes, as if we're condensing the beings of darkness, pushing them into the few remaining cramped corners. Unfortunately for us, the less we accept the night, embrace the darkness, the more it seeps into us, corrupts our actions and refracts our rays of thought. Beware the lack of dark spaces, it flatters you not, contorted features, darkened, deepened shadows.
The quality that we call beauty, however, must always grow from the realities of life, and our ancestors, forced to live in dark rooms, presently came to discover beauty in shadows, ultimately to guide shadows towards beauty’s ends. Jun'ichirō Tanizaki, In Praise of Shadows

item.title: Lack of empathy
item.description:
Empathy is the sharing and understanding of someone else's feelings or, at the very least, an attempt. It is about relating to others through one's own experiences, picturing oneself in their position. Empathy is, if you will, the precursor to compassion. No empathy, no compassion, no compassion, no collective action to alleviate the sufferings of other beings.

item.title: Lack of faith in anything
item.description:
You get worse and worse. And all this talking is useless because you'll all turn to mush anyway. I'll go lay in the hammock and think. Goodbye for now in case we never see each other again. The Muskrat (Tove Jansson), Comet in Moominland
To lack faith is to lack the belief that there is any possibility of betterment, redemption, to lack trust in someone or something to make itself present. It also means lacking the confidence of what should result from certain actions. Without faith in a process of development one gets nowhere, but then again maybe finding that faith is a part of the process. In early Buddhism, faith focused on the triratna, the so called three jewels. These could, in a broader context, be seen as the faith in the good, the faith in the teachings of the good, and the community seeking to learn from that teaching. Even more generally, do you believe there is a divine good within? Do you believe this good moves us towards certain actions and views when the mind is still? Do you believe there are others with you in this? I hope there are readers who answer yes to this.

item.title: Lack of feeling needed
item.description:

What you do with and about this change is up to you. Modernity has, however, created the predicament that few, if any, feel needed. item.title: Lack of historical insight
item.description:
Disregard history and you will slowly erase your own future. History matters greatly. History contains other ways of being, living, thinking, acting, talking, seeing, and perceiving. It provides the richness needed for the emergence of cultures and, further, the cultivation of people. However, it is equally important to learn how to think about history. One model of historical thinking provides five key concepts: change over time, causality, context, complexity, and contingency. Things change in ways we might not understand, even with hindsight, causality chains are seldom linear or simple, everything must be understood in the context of its place and time, everything is always endlessly complex, contingent events, or black swans, are improbable and inevitable at the same time.

item.title: Lack of humility
item.description:
Humility means an understanding of our place in the web of life, a willingness to see truth, and an openness to the value and meaning of the seemingly meaningless. Being humble is being firmly planted in the ground of reality.
We humans have undoubtedly, in some ways, gotten far along certain paths of progress or thought-manifestations. However, we lose our humility when our feet leave the humus of the Earth. A tree that reaches towards the heavens while forsaking its roots quickly dies. There is no honour in mere grandeur, we must keep our feet and roots in the ground of reality.

item.title: Lack of love
item.description:
What is required is an attentive response to something real and other than ourselves, of which we have only inklings at first, but which comes more and more into being through our response to it – if we are truly responsive to it. We nurture it into being; or not. In this it has something of the structure of love. Iain McGilchrist
Love is the extremely difficult realization that something other than oneself is real. Iris Murdoch
I feel more hesitant towards writing about this predicament than any of the others. I do not want to explain what love is, define it, pin it down. Nor do I really want to dig into the consequences of its absence. Call it what you will but everything within me senses a gravity to this predicament, a point of singularity in the landscape. The absence of love leaves us more blind than the absence of light.
Love is a striking example of how little reality means to us. Marcel Proust
Although we say mountains belong to the country, actually, they belong to those that love them. Dogen Zenji

item.title: Lack of purpose
item.description:
What does it mean to have a purpose or, perhaps more importantly, to lack purpose? A purpose is an intention, aim, or goal. It is something put forth, proposed, something to be kept in view, the proper and unique reason for something's existence. Do you have a purpose? Do humans have a purpose? What about other beings? What about the sun? Whatever one answers to these questions it will shape the world one inhabits, make something of it and with it, and allow for the presence of some purposes and the absence of others. If you share humanity's lack of purpose in general, maybe there is a meta-purpose in living with the question of what the proper reason for one's own and humanity's existence could be?
Who made the world?
Who made the swan, and the black bear?
Who made the grasshopper?
This grasshopper, I mean-
the one who has flung herself out of the grass,
the one who is eating sugar out of my hand,
who is moving her jaws back and forth instead of up and down-
who is gazing around with her enormous and complicated eyes.
Now she lifts her pale forearms and thoroughly washes her face.
Now she snaps her wings open, and floats away.
I don't know exactly what a prayer is.
I do know how to pay attention, how to fall down
into the grass, how to kneel down in the grass,
how to be idle and blessed, how to stroll through the fields,
which is what I have been doing all day.
Tell me, what else should I have done?
Doesn't everything die at last, and too soon?
Tell me, what is it you plan to do
with your one wild and precious life? Mary Oliver

item.title: Lack of quiet spaces
item.description:
The issue which I propose for discussion should therefore be clear: how to counter the encroachment of new, electronic devices and systems upon commons that are more subtle and more intimate to our being than either grassland or roads - commons that are at least as valuable as silence. Silence, according to western and eastern tradition alike, is necessary for the emergence of persons. It is taken from us by machines that ape people. We could easily be made increasingly dependent on machines for speaking and for thinking, as we are already dependent on machines for moving. Ivan Illich, Silence as a Commons
Few, if any, places remain on our planet that aren't polluted with anthropogenic sounds. The hum of highways, airplane engines high above, tires ripping hot asphalt, titanium angels cutting clouds. The most profound wisdom lies in the depth of silence, a silence that is going extinct. Every human should have access to a place without human-made sounds, and so should every other animal. In the words of Miles Davis, "it's not the note you play that's the wrong note - it's the note you play afterwards that makes it right or wrong". The unlearning of the modern chaotic cacophony, the notes currently played, can only be made right if what follows is a silence and harmony unbounded.
Always listen for what you can leave out. Miles Davis

item.title: Lack of resilient systems
item.description:
Resilient systems have the ability to leap back into equilibrium and adapt to changing conditions.
When systems are designed to be rigid, static, simple, and centralised they tend to lack resilience and instead collapse in a destabilising event. Many of our civilisation's systems are so interdependent that any destabilising event can create detrimental cascade effects that affect everyone. If we take the chance to redesign our systems we need to design more resilient systems that can adapt to novel situations, stay functional despite major disruptions, and allow for emergent and complex responses.
Let's face it, the universe is messy. It is nonlinear, turbulent, and chaotic. It is dynamic. It spends its time in transient behavior on its way to somewhere else, not in mathematically neat equilibria. It self-organizes and evolves. It creates diversity, not uniformity. That's what makes the world interesting, that's what makes it beautiful, and that's what makes it work. Donella Meadows
Importantly, we must also make sure that we do not become, or keep being, the disruption that ruins existing resilient systems. There are few systems resilient to the destructive capabilities of our civilisation but it is crucial that those that still exist, such as the Amazon or the atmosphere, are kept alive.

item.title: Lack of systems thinking
item.description:
The systems-thinking lens allows us to reclaim our intuition about whole systems and hone our abilities to understand parts, see interconnections, ask “what-if ” questions about possible future behaviors, and be creative and courageous about system redesign. Donella Meadows
Systems thinking is a way of making sense of the complexity of the world by looking at it in terms of wholes and relationships rather than by splitting it down into its parts. Instead of trying to find singular causes or reductionistically define overall behaviour from the behaviour of subsystems, systems thinkers tend to look at a system's dynamics, complex behaviours, feedback loops, leverage points, etc. Systems thinking is a requirement for understanding the complex connections between predicaments and how to manage them.
Those who do not apply systems thinking to their decisions and actions will constantly be unpleasantly surprised by the unpredictability of their results. Oh, systems thinkers will also have unpredictable results, they're just slightly less surprised.
God grant us the serenity to exercise our bounded rationality freely in the systems that are structured appropriately, the courage to restructure the systems that aren’t, and the wisdom to know the difference! Donella Meadows

item.title: Lack of the longterm
item.description:
Modernity is controlled by the economic system and, in extension, politicians, institutions, business corporations, and the market. Most political terms are four years and in finance there is often talk of seven year market cycles. Most large-scale decisions fall within this range of time. It is unquestionable that we have a tendency to focus on the short-term. The seven year market cycle can be contrasted with something believed to originate in the Great Law of the Iroquois, namely the seven generation stewardship. This concept urges the current generation to live and work for the benefit of the seventh generation into the future. What would we do differently if we lived and worked to benefit the seventh generation into the future?

item.title: Lack of time
item.description:
In philosophy if you aren't moving at a snail's pace you aren't moving at all. Iris Murdoch
We lack time in a multitude of ways. I would, however, separate our lack of time into two categories, one being duration and the other being the prioritisation of the present moment. There is a feeling of impending doom in many people, that there isn't enough time to course correct, to halt global warming, to stop the machine before it kills us. The future is shrinking, we lack continuance of time, instead strengthening our hearts awaiting the crash with a hardened future. The second category, the prioritisation of the present, is what makes the changes that are required even less likely to happen. We, as individuals, communities, societies, nations, don't have time to spend on slowing down or halting certain activities while doubling down on others. We don't have time to not be employed, grow the economy, travel, provide, we don't have time to not destroy the world. If we must spend our time destroying it, how can we even attempt to prioritise saving it at any moment?
Of these two categories, I would implore you to ignore the former and focus on the latter. Eternity does not lie in duration, it lies in the infinitely complex web of the moment. To find a way forward, every step of every moment has to be radical and daring.
It's too late to be ready. Dogen Zenji

item.title: Lack of visions
item.description:
We cannot know his legendary head
with eyes like ripening fruit. And yet his torso
is still suffused with brilliance from inside,
like a lamp, in which his gaze, now turned to low, gleams in all its power. Otherwise
the curved breast could not dazzle you so, nor could
a smile run through the placid hips and thighs
to that dark center where procreation flared. Otherwise this stone would seem defaced
beneath the translucent cascade of the shoulders
and would not glisten like a wild beast's fur: would not, from all the borders of itself,
burst like a star: for here there is no place
that does not see you. You must change your life. Rainer Maria Rilke, Archaic Torso of Apollo
There has occurred a narrowing of the future, a closing off. Instead of a future open with possibilities and visions of beauty, we seem resigned to the direction of our inertia. The visions that do exist seem hubristic and speaks to an ever shrinking minority of optimistic elites. Few people envision a distant future of peace, prosperity, beauty, wisdom, science, brilliance, love, community, friendship, and coherence. Is the future so dark that it denies vision? We must then withdraw from the order of events and create visions whose light comes from within, see them before they're visible.

item.title: Language

The Potawatomi language consists of around 70% verbs compared to 30% in the English language. Why would that matter? The world of the Potawatomi is alive, being, doing, becoming. It is also nearly impossible to escape the frames of one's language in imagination and thinking processes.
It is hard, today, to imagine that the word of a poet was once feared by a king. Dougald Hine & Paul Kingsnorth, Dark Mountain Manifesto

item.title: Limits to growth
item.description:
The ultimate meaning to which all stories refer has two faces: the continuity of life, the inevitability of death. Italo Calvino
There are limits to growth in a finite system. What happens in the interaction between Earth's and humanity's systems when humanity tries to grow indefinitely?
Lets look at what the limits might be. The Limits to Growth report bases their model on five variables: population, food production, industrialisation, pollution, and consumption of nonrenewable natural resources. I think an even simpler way of looking at limits to growth is looking at input requirements and output management. If a set of systems requires an input of finite resources larger than the renewal of that resource it will deplete that resource. Also, if a set of systems produces waste that is larger than it can manage through reuse, recycling, or removal it will eventually cause irreversible disruption.
The Limits to Growth further concludes that if growth continues the most probable result is rapid, sudden, and uncontrollable decline in population and industrial capacity; that it is possible to alter these growth trends to establish a condition of ecological and economic stability that is indefinitely sustainable; and that the chances of succeeding in altering these trends increase the earlier we start striving for it. This report was written in 1972.
These conclusions are so far-reaching and raise so many questions for further study that we are quite frankly overwhelmed by the enormity of the job that must be done. We hope that this book will serve to interest other people, in many fields of study and in many countries of the world, to raise the space and time horizons of their concerns, and to join us in understanding and preparing for a period of great transition – the transition from growth to global equilibrium. The Limits to Growth
The Limits to Growth report has been criticised from many angles and there are of course important additions such as the effect of technological development on the possibilities for further growth. The problem with the technology argument is treated in other predicaments but put simply when related to the limits to growth, we will not escape the fact that humans need resources and a way to manage its waste and we are not closer to solving this with technology now than we were during the writing of the original 1972 report.

item.title: Loss of cultural complexity
item.description:
Culture encompasses the social behaviours, norms, institutions, knowledge, beliefs, arts, laws, capabilities, customs, individual habits, and more of groups in human societies. When most cultures fall into the same system the complexity of cultures overall will be reduced. The less cultural complexity the lower the chance that human societies can respond to societal disruptions. This loss of cultural complexity is two-sided. On one side we have a reduction in the complexity of each culture since behaviours, norms, etc must follow the requirements of the global economic systems. In other words, the cultures that exist are becoming more similar, somehow while continuing to polarise, a paradox for another time. The other side is the complete disappearing of cultures that begun with the start of colonialism which continues to this day, with people dying together with their culture.

item.title: Malnutrition
item.description:
Let food be thy medicine and medicine be thy food. Hippocrates
Malnutrition is a deficiency, excess, or imbalance of energy, protein, and other vital nutrients. Malnutrition therefore includes both starvation and obesity and it is estimated that around 30% of the global population has some form of malnutrition. With our knowledge of diet and the excess of available food it is nothing less than a tragedy that we have failed completely in getting nutrition right. Rest assured that it is not simply an unfortunate coincidence or personal failings, rather it is rooted in the many underlying systems of modernity.
Malnutrition, away from definitions, can also include factors that are more difficult to quantify. The food we eat make up who we become and this includes the soil it grows in, the air that surrounds it, how it was cooked, who cooked it, the bacteria it contains, the way its eaten, etc. Many revolutions have been started at a dinner table.

item.title: Map and territory
item.description:
The map is not the territory. No model or perception of reality can represent the entirety of actual reality. Importantly, the maps you use affect your view of reality. Coast lines are infinite, fractal, endless. Maps must choose a scale. Maps are abstractions of reality such as explanations, descriptions, theories, models, etc. Maps are useful and necessary to make sense of life and the world. However, using these maps require two vital points of understanding. Firstly, we must understand what the maps claim to capture. What is their focus, what has been ignored, what are the limits, which scale is chosen and why, what do the maps try to make sense of, etc. The models describing atoms and molecules can give insight into the properties of physical matter but it won't tell you how to get from Paris to Tokyo, or how to play the drums. There are other maps for that. Secondly, a map can never and will never capture all of reality. It will always be an abstraction, an approximation. If you use maps, models, theories, etc with these two points in mind, you'll stay out of most map-related trouble. Stray from these two, however, and you'll be so lost that you've left the territory.
"That's another thing we've learned from your Nation," said Mein Herr, "map-making. But we've carried it much further than you. What do you consider the largest map that would be really useful?" "About six inches to the mile." "Only six inches!" exclaimed Mein Herr. "We very soon got to six yards to the mile. Then we tried a hundred yards to the mile. And then came the grandest idea of all! We actually made a map of the country, on the scale of a mile to the mile!" "Have you used it much?" I enquired. "It has never been spread out, yet," said Mein Herr: "the farmers objected: they said it would cover the whole country, and shut out the sunlight! So we now use the country itself, as its own map, and I assure you it does nearly as well." Lewis Carroll, Sylvie and Bruno Concluded

item.title: Maximum power principle
item.description:
The maximum power principle can be stated: During self-organization, system designs develop and prevail that maximize power intake, energy transformation, and those uses that reinforce production and efficiency. Howard T. Odum
The maximum power principle, as a fourth law of thermodynamics, is used as a principle to quantitatively describe biological evolution as the maximum rate of useful energy transformation for any biological system. More simply stated (by A.J. Lotka) "the advantage must go to those organisms whose energy-capturing devices are most efficient in [using the energy for] the preservation of the species".
Another way of looking at it is that whoever manages to acquire and utilise the most power will live. Those who don't won't.

item.title: Meat eating
item.description:
Whether or not one's diet should include meat is, in this case, better discussed elsewhere, though it should, in this landscape, be quite obvious where the arrows point. Nonetheless, meat consumption as an ethical, environmental, and health-related predicament is, I believe, quite clear.
Ethics aside, speaking the language of modernity meat consumption is so ludicrously inefficient when it comes to land use. We require a tremendous amount of land to raise livestock and the caloric extraction is increasingly more inefficient the further away from the main source we go. It is estimated that it takes around 100 times as much land to produce a kilocalorie of beef versus the equivalent plant-based alternative and, before you speak, the same is true for a gram of protein. Is modernity really obsessed with efficiency and intelligent solutions?
I will also add that there are certain arguments claiming we should eat meat that I find attractive but unconvincing. They always sound something like "to truly be part of life, we must also be part of death, and to keep the world and ourselves healthy we must live side by side with grazing animals... and eat them in their prime". Okay, I slightly modified the last bit but you get the gist of it. Death is undoubtedly a part of life and everything we do in and for life has its mirrored acts in and for death. But if I lived in a community that argued that we needed to live side by side with other people who were then harvested for organs, blood, and meat in their prime... Well, I think I'd go live somewhere else. The poetic argument that there is beauty in the fact that the cow you eat contains the life force of everything it ate living off the land sounds to me like an attempt to dress one's desire for beef in poetic justification. After all, compared to every other animal on Earth humans have the ability to adapt their ways of living almost indefinitely. Why not pick a way of peace?

item.title: Mental health
item.description:
Nothing
in the world
is usual today.
This is
the first morning. Izumi Shikibu
We, as humans, have not evolved for the ways of living modernity offers. Mental health encompasses emotional, psychological, and social well-being, influencing cognition, perception, and behaviour. Mental illness is therefore any long-term negatively affecting emotional or psychological condition which affects cognition, perception, behaviour, and overall well-being. Many mental illnesses are direct adaptations to the life of modernity, ways of managing the dissonance of a life with several needs and wants forever unmet, where some management methods end up being coincidentally beneficial and some crippling. I would even go so far as to say that those who are perfectly mentally healthy in the modern world are more worrying than those who aren't and I would, consequently, quite confidently, say that the cognition, perception, and behaviour required to be truly happy while balls-deep in modernity is the real illness.

item.title: Microplastics
item.description:
Microplastics are small fragments of any type of plastic (<5 mm). Unless they are designed to be biodegradable they tend to accumulate in the environment, particularly in water but also the air and soil. They are mobile, persistent, and difficult to remove from nature. Over 80% of the microplastic in the environment comes from textiles, tires, and city dust. The environmental and health impacts of microplastics are uncertain but it isn't unreasonable to think that an accumulation of synthetic non-degradable material in all living organisms could end up being catastrophic.
Although man’s record as a steward of the natural resources of the earth has been a discouraging one, there has long been a certain comfort in the belief that the sea, at least, was inviolate, beyond man’s ability to change and to despoil. But this belief, unfortunately, has proved to be naïve. Rachel Carson, The Sea Around Us

item.title: Mind-body separation
item.description:
Let me begin with a left-brained approach to illustrating how at fault we are when we assume ourselves to be minds or brains living in a casing of flesh. The brain consists of neurons and the amount of neurons seem to correlate quite well with an animal's intelligence, in a way. Our gut has more neurons than the brain of a dog. How, then, are your thoughts separated from your "gut feelings"?
I have difficulty even entertaining the thought for longer than I already have in this example. There is no boundary, no separation, between mind and body. Even talking about mind and body as separate things shows my own inclination towards distinction. Your body is your mind, your mind is your body, you are both, your mind together with your body is your connection to the world which you are also. Take that and run with it or do what you will.
We inevitably create difficulties for ourselves when we see mind and body as separate and it is, frankly, ridiculous of a supposedly intelligent being to hold such delusions.

item.title: Mistreatment of animals
item.description:
It is not unreasonable to make the case that there has never in the history of the Earth existed a more prolonged and systematic creation of suffering than the current mistreatment of animals, specifically animals used in the production of food. Those humans who manage to climb out of the collapsed rubble of modernity will surely see our mistreatment of animals as the biggest moral crime in all of history, the most terrible nightmare, the darkest and most evil of industrial demons, the thorn in the belief in the good of their own species.
About a million cows are slaughtered every day, around 3 million goats and sheep, close to 4 million pigs, 12 million ducks, and hundreds of millions of fish. 140,000 chickens are slaughtered each minute. If you believe animals suffer at all, even just the tiniest amount, the moral scale of these actions is immense beyond imagining.
I can sometimes find certain justifications believable, especially when actions have very complex impacts that aren't directly obvious. Any justification for the efficient incessant holocaust machinery that our meat consumption requires is simply ridiculous.
We shouldn't, of course, forget the impact humans have on wild animals, or maybe it would be more accurate to say the impact it has had on wild animals, since there are very few left. Since the rise of humans around a hundred thousand years ago there has been an 85% decline in terrestrial wild mammal biomass and we can now quite confidently claim that we are living through an anthropogenic extinction event. 4% of the Earth's mammals are wild and we're working on getting them extinct, 34% percent are humans, the remaining 62% are our pets or live short lives in factories of death. One shouldn't get caught up in numbers but I think that says enough.

item.title: Mistreatment of other humans
item.description:
A fool sees himself as another, but a wise man sees others as himself. Dogen Zenji
Quite an obvious one, is it not? Although, I would claim that as a predicament this one points to two separate mistreatments of other humans. One is the deliberate and intentional mistreatment of humans, unrelated to what motivates said mistreatment. Killing, raping, enslaving, abusing, isolating, marginalising, excluding, etc. The other, more fickle, all-encompassing, and hidden is the global systemic mistreatment of other humans somehow unfit for the life of modernity. There exist no righteous, reasonable, or even acceptable motivations for the mistreatment of those who stand in the way of the stampede of modernity and, sadly, the more crippled, blind, and injured modernity becomes the less it cares about what it tramples as it moves ahead.
The main issue with this predicament is that most of us don't recognise or acknowledge our complicity in the mistreatment of other humans. Why should we? Aren't we enlightened and good people? Well, no, it might be true for christmas presents but for most actions it is not the thought that counts.

item.title: Modern slavery

I have found that, to make a contented slave, it is necessary to make a thoughtless one. It is necessary to darken his moral and mental vision, and, as far as possible, to annihilate the power of reason. item.title: Monocultures (agriculture)
item.description:
Agricultural monocultures, or the practice of monocropping, means growing the same crop on the same land year after year. The main reasons for monocropping is the potential overall profitability, productivity, and efficiency. Another important reason for monocropping is predictability. When timber came from planted rows of trees instead of complex forests it became much easier to calculate current and future yields. Like many other predicaments agricultural monocultures provide potential short-term benefits while likely resulting in long-term cascades of problems.

item.title: Multipolar traps
item.description:
Multipolar traps are some of the most prevalent generator functions of existential risks and one of, if not the most difficult challenge humankind has ever faced. But what are multipolar traps? They are game theory power plays. One way to look at multipolar traps is as a variation on the tragedy of the commons, where different entities compete over a resource and through their own self-interest deplete the resource for themselves and everyone else. The reason for this happening is that if there is enough resources around for everyone it only requires one entity being slightly greedy for everyone else to be incentivised to do the same in order to ensure their own survival. So, since our entity is "good" we should, before all this happens, trust in our understanding of game theory and extract as much of that resource as we can so we can ensure that the other entities don't do it first. It was simply the right thing to do. Game theory-wise, and tragedy of the commons-wise. Raise this behaviour up a notch and include exponential power and technology and you have multipolar traps.
I don't believe a single person in the world feels stoked about the existence of AI-controlled nuclear drones, yet every major military power is developing them as fast as they possibly can. We are stuck in a race to become the one entity that survives. And now, since this race requires different types of vital resources, has become global, and is driven by such power, we might slowly come to realise, I hope, that what we are racing towards is to become the first entity to destroy everything. If we do not figure out how to solve multipolar traps, acquire the wisdom to manage them, these traps will guarantee the complete collapse of civilisation and the extinction of most life on Earth.
Many of the negative cascade effects that can arise out of the connections in the Predicament Landscape are multipolar traps and it is therefore of the highest importance to develop an understanding for both the interconnectedness and interdependence of different predicaments.

item.title: Naive progress narrative
item.description:
The current dominating mainstream narrative of humanity is a narrative of progress. Specifically, it tends to relate to technological innovation as a fundamental driver of history. Technology determines the fate of us all, from our entire modern civilisation to each individual, so the narrative claims. What does it mean to be naive in ones view of progress as opposed to having an intelligent and wise view of progress? And why does this narrative matter?
In the naïveté there hides several problems of scale or span, both in time and space. Certain fields and areas have undoubtedly seen much progress, however, it all depends on what is included in the word progress. If to progress is to move forward it is valuable to understand what one is moving forward towards as well as what one is moving away from. Also, what is and is not included in this forward-movement?
Is the notion of progress at all useful for organisms? What would it mean for wolves or fungi to progress?

item.title: Nihilism
item.description:
Those are my enemies: they want to overthrow and to construct nothing themselves. They say: "All that is worthless"--and want to create no value themselves. Friedrich Nietzsche
Nihilism is a set of philosophical views that rejects certain aspects of human existence, such as knowledge, morality, or meaning. Life is meaningless, there is nothing such as knowledge and wisdom, everything is pointless, worthless, and without value. Nihilism, etymologically, simply means nothingness. There is, therefore, nothing behind, within, or underneath it all. The world, existence, consciousness, the soul, all is one big nothingness. In some ways I can agree with nihilists that underneath all of everything there is no-thingness. There is something else. Nihilists believe in nothing and have nothing to lose, see nothing in values, ethics, or the continued existence of the world, or even that their actions have any effect on anything that matters.
The man of the future who will redeem us not only from the hitherto reigning ideal but also from that which was bound to grow out of it, the great nausea, the will to nothingness, nihilism; this bell stroke of noon and of the great decision that liberates the will again and restores its goal to the earth and his hope to man; this Antichrist and anti-nihilist; this victor over God and nothingness - he must come one day. Friedrich Nietzsche

item.title: No precautionary principle
item.description:

The precautionary principle states that when developing something one must first work to ensure that its coming into being will not be catastrophically threatening, and only build it when one is confident about this. Modern technological development goes by the opposite principle. If there isn't definite proof that something is catastrophically threatening one can develop and build anything. There is no possibility for hindsight after the development of catastrophically threatening technologies.
